Regent diamond: A famous diamond of fine quality, which weighs about 137 carats and is among the state jewels of France. It is so called from the Duke of Orleans, Regent of France, to whom it was sold in 1717 by Pitt the English Governor of Madras (whence also called the Pitt diamond), who bought it of an Indian merchant in 1701.
Rusine: Of, like, or pertaining to, a deer of the genus Rusa, which includes the sambur deer (Rusa Aristotelis) of India.
Roofing: The act of covering with a roof.
&Verbar;Retiarius: A gladiator armed with a net for entangling his adversary and a trident for despatching him.
Residential: Of or pertaining to a residence or residents; as, residential trade; a residential part of town.
Rout: To assemble in a crowd, whether orderly or disorderly; to collect in company.
Retarded: having a limited or below normal mental ability; same as mentally retarded; -- used especially in relation to performance in academic tasks.
Radiative: Capable of radiating; acting by radiation.
Recadency: A falling back or descending a second time; a relapse.
Remorseless: Being without remorse; having no pity; hence, destitute of sensibility; cruel; insensible to distress; merciless.
Ritualistic: Pertaining to, or in accordance with, a ritual; adhering to ritualism.
Rachitome: A dissecting instrument for opening the spinal canal.
Rubicelle: A variety of ruby of a yellowish red color, from Brazil.
Rusticity: The quality or state of being rustic; rustic manners; rudeness; simplicity; artlessness.
Rhinencephalic: Of or pertaining to the rhinencephalon.
Reverted: Turned back; reversed. Specifically: (Her.) Bent or curved twice, in opposite directions, or in the form of an S.
Rubiform: Having the nature or quality of red; as, the rubiform rays of the sun.
Reflect: To throw back light, heat, or the like; to return rays or beams.
Reargument: An arguing over again, as of a motion made in court.
Restrainer: One who, or that which, restrains.
Ranger: One who ranges; a rover; sometimes, one who ranges for plunder; a roving robber.
Relaxation: The act or process of relaxing, or the state of being relaxed; as, relaxation of the muscles; relaxation of a law.
Returnable: Capable of, or admitting of, being returned.
Rocking: Having a swaying, rolling, or back-and-forth movement; used for rocking.
Reintegrate: To renew with regard to any state or quality; to restore; to bring again together into a whole, as the parts off anything; to reestablish; as, to reintegrate a nation.
Right-lined: Formed by right lines; rectilineal; as, a right-lined angle.
Resection: The act of cutting or paring off.
Reedling: The European bearded titmouse (Panurus biarmicus); -- called also reed bunting, bearded pinnock, and lesser butcher bird.
Redaction: The act of redacting; work produced by redacting; a digest.
Ripsaw: A handsaw with coarse teeth which have but a slight set, used for cutting wood in the direction of the grain (the fiber); -- called also ripping saw.
&Verbar;Retinophora: One of group of two to four united cells which occupy the axial part of the ocelli, or ommatidia, of the eyes of invertebrates, and contain the terminal nerve fibrillæ. See Illust. under Ommatidium.
Resigned: Submissive; yielding; not disposed to resist or murmur.
Reasoner: One who reasons or argues; as, a fair reasoner; a close reasoner; a logical reasoner.
Rooster: The male of the domestic fowl; a cock.
&Verbar;Rhe\u00e6: A suborder of struthious birds including the rheas.
Roup: An outcry; hence, a sale of gods by auction.
&Verbar;R\u00e9molade: A kind of piquant sauce or salad dressing resembling mayonnaise.
Regnal: Of or pertaining to the reign of a monarch; as, regnal years.
Reputedly: In common opinion or estimation; by repute.
Reinette: A name given to many different kinds of apples, mostly of French origin.
Ramiform: Having the form of a branch.
Rambling: Roving; wandering; discursive; as, a rambling fellow, talk, or building.
Regenerateness: The quality or state of being rgenerate.
Remigrate: To migrate again; to go back; to return.
Retuse: Having the end rounded and slightly indented; as, a retuse leaf.
Remount: The opportunity of, or things necessary for, remounting; specifically, a fresh horse, with his equipments; as, to give one a remount.
Regiment: To form into a regiment or into regiments.
Rambooze: A beverage made of wine, ale (or milk), sugar, etc.
Rugate: Having alternate ridges and depressions; wrinkled.
R\u00f6ntgen: Of or pertaining to the German physicist Wilhelm Konrad Röntgen, or the rays discovered by him; as, Röntgen apparatus.
Rustle: A quick succession or confusion of small sounds, like those made by shaking leaves or straw, by rubbing silk, or the like; a rustling.
Rotor: The rotating part of a generator or motor.  Contrasted with stator, the stationary part.
Replait: To plait or fold again; to fold, as one part over another, again and again.
Romanize: To use Latin words and idioms.
Retribute: To pay back; to give in return, as payment, reward, or punishment; to requite; as, to retribute one for his kindness; to retribute just punishment to a criminal.
Reindeer: Any ruminant of the genus Rangifer, of the Deer family, found in the colder parts of both the Eastern and Western hemispheres, and having long irregularly branched antlers, with the brow tines palmate.
Redemptive: Serving or tending to redeem; redeeming; as, the redemptive work of Christ.
Rheotome: An instrument which periodically or otherwise interrupts an electric current.
Reconcentrate: To concentrate again; to concentrate thoroughly.
Russianize: To make Russian, or more or less like the Russians; as, to Russianize the Poles.
Revaccinate: To vaccinate a second time or again.
Renal: Of or pertaining to the kidneys; in the region of the kidneys.
Rhodophane: The red pigment contained in the inner segments of the cones of the retina in animals. See Chromophane.
Reissners membrane: The thin membrane which separates the canal of the cochlea from the vestibular scala in the internal ear.
Remissness: Quality or state of being remiss.
Retrench: To cause or suffer retrenchment; specifically, to cut down living expenses; as, it is more reputable to retrench than to live embarrassed.
Reprehensory: Containing reproof; reprehensive; as, reprehensory complaint.
Reassemblage: Assemblage a second time or again.
Rigor: The becoming stiff or rigid; the state of being rigid; rigidity; stiffness; hardness.
Rimose: Full of rimes, fissures, or chinks.
Raspberry: The thimble-shaped fruit of the Rubus Idæus and other similar brambles; as, the black, the red, and the white raspberry.
&Verbar;R\u00e9chauff\u00e9: A dish of food that has been warmed again, hence, fig., something made up from old material; a rehash.
Reticent: Inclined to keep silent; reserved; uncommunicative.
Rocoa: The orange-colored pulp covering the seeds of the tropical plant Bixa Orellana, from which annotto is prepared. See Annoto.
Retrievable: That may be retrieved or recovered; admitting of retrieval.
Reflux: A flowing back, as the return of a fluid; ebb; reaction; as, the flux and reflux of the tides.
&Verbar;Rodentia: An order of mammals having two (rarely four) large incisor teeth in each jaw, distant from the molar teeth. The rats, squirrels, rabbits, marmots, and beavers belong to this order.
&Verbar;Rez-de-chauss\u00e9e: The ground story of a building, either on a level with the street or raised slightly above it; -- said esp. of buildings on the continent of Europe.
Rounded: Modified by contraction of the lip opening; labialized; labial. See Guide to Pronunciation, § 11.
Retroactive: Fitted or designed to retroact; operating by returned action; affecting what is past; retrospective.
Rubidine: A nitrogenous base homologous with pyridine, obtained from coal tar as an oily liquid, C11H17N; also, any one of the group od metameric compounds of which rubidine is the type.
Resail: To sail again; also, to sail back, as to a former port.
Recitative: Of or pertaining to recitation; intended for musical recitation or declamation; in the style or manner of recitative.
Rendering: The act of one who renders, or that which is rendered.
Residentship: The office or condition of a resident.
Rigidness: The quality or state of being rigid.
&Verbar;Repouss\u00e9: Formed in relief, as a pattern on metal.
Receptacle: That which serves, or is used, for receiving and containing something, as for examople, a basket, a vase, a bag, a reservoir; a repository.
Ruling: The act of one who rules; ruled lines.
Resurgence: The act of rising again; resurrection.
Reversioner: One who has a reversion, or who is entitled to lands or tenements, after a particular estate granted is terminated.
Recur: To come back; to return again or repeatedly; to come again to mind.
Ruffianish: Having the qualities or manners of a ruffian; ruffianly.
&Verbar;Raki: A kind of ardent spirits used in southern Europe and the East, distilled from grape juice, grain, etc.
Revolver: One who, or that which, revolves; specifically, a firearm ( commonly a pistol) with several chambers or barrels so arranged as to revolve on an axis, and be discharged in succession by the same lock; a repeater.
Radicate: To cause to take root; to plant deeply and firmly; to root.
Retaliate: To return like for like; specifically, to return evil for evil; as, to retaliate upon an enemy.
Refect: To restore after hunger or fatigue; to refresh.
Romaic: Of or relating to modern Greece, and especially to its language.
Recompose: To compose again; to form anew; to put together again or repeatedly.
Respirative: Of or pertaining to respiration; as, respirative organs.
Resoluble: Admitting of being resolved; resolvable; as, bodies resoluble by fire.
Rheometer: An instrument for measuring currents, especially the force or intensity of electrical currents; a galvanometer.
Rectoral: Pertaining to a rector or governor.
&Verbar;Ronde: A kind of script in which the heavy strokes are nearly upright, giving the characters when taken together a round look.
Recent: Of late origin, existence, or occurrence; lately come; not of remote date, antiquated style, or the like; not already known, familiar, worn out, trite, etc.; fresh; novel; new; modern; as, recent news.
Radiate-veined: Having the principal veins radiating, or diverging, from the apex of the petiole; -- said of such leaves as those of the grapevine, most maples, and the castor-oil plant.
Russophobe: One who dreads Russia or Russian influence.
Roughtail: Any species of small ground snakes of the family Uropeltidæ; -- so called from their rough tails.
&Verbar;Rhopalium: One of the marginal sensory bodies of medusæ belonging to the Discophora.
Restorer: One who, or that which, restores.
Ramp: A leap; a spring; a hostile advance.
Resumable: Capable of, or admitting of, being resumed.
Rabinet: A kind of small ordnance formerly in use.
Ripost: In fencing, a return thrust after a parry.
Redeemable: Capable of being redeemed; subject to repurchase; held under conditions permitting redemption; as, a pledge securing the payment of money is redeemable.
&Verbar;Rhizopoda: An extensive class of Protozoa, including those which have pseudopodia, by means of which they move about and take their food. The principal groups are Lobosa (or Amœbea), Helizoa, Radiolaria, and Foraminifera (or Reticularia). See Protozoa.
Recant: To revoke a declaration or proposition; to unsay what has been said; to retract; as, convince me that I am wrong, and I will recant.
Reposit: To cause to rest or stay; to lay away; to lodge, as for safety or preservation; to place; to store.
Run: Melted, or made from molten material; cast in a mold; as, run butter; run iron or lead.
Reiterative: A word expressing repeated or reiterated action.
Rocket scientist: a very intelligent person; -- used mostly in the phrases: “you don't have to be a rocket scientist to . . .” and “it doesn't take a rocket scientist to . . .”, meaning that the subject that follows is easy to understand.
Rostral: Of or pertaining to the beak or snout of an animal, or the beak of a ship; resembling a rostrum, esp., the rostra at Rome, or their decorations.
Retreat: To make a retreat; to retire from any position or place; to withdraw; as, the defeated army retreated from the field.
Redemand: A demanding back; a second or renewed demand.
Ragmans roll: The rolls of deeds on parchment in which the Scottish nobility and gentry subscribed allegiance to Edward I. of England, A. D. 1296.
Riotous: Involving, or engaging in, riot; wanton; unrestrained; luxurious.
Rangership: The office of the keeper of a forest or park.
Rhinology: The science which treats of the nose, and its diseases.
Reticular: Having the form of a net, or of network; formed with interstices; retiform; as, reticular cartilage; a reticular leaf.
&Verbar;Rancheria: A dwelling place of a ranchero.
Resiniferous: Yielding resin; as, a resiniferous tree or vessel.
Reticulate: Resembling network; having the form or appearance of a net; netted; as, a reticulated structure.
Rebutter: The answer of a defendant in matter of fact to a plaintiff's surrejoinder.
Right whale: The bowhead, Arctic, or Greenland whale (Balæna mysticetus), from whose mouth the best whalebone is obtained.
Ralph: A name sometimes given to the raven.
Reciprocality: The quality or condition of being reciprocal; reciprocalness.
Reality: The state or quality of being real; actual being or existence of anything, in distinction from mere appearance; fact.
Reactive: Having power to react; tending to reaction; of the nature of reaction.
Roustabout: A laborer, especially a deck hand, on a river steamboat, who moves the cargo, loads and unloads wood, and the like; in an opprobrious sense, a shiftless vagrant who lives by chance jobs.
Regenerate: To generate or produce anew; to reproduce; to give new life, strength, or vigor to.
Routinary: Involving, or pertaining to, routine; ordinary; customary.
Remast: To furnish with a new mast or set of masts.
Refreshful: Full of power to refresh; refreshing.
Rainfall: A fall or descent of rain; the water, or amount of water, that falls in rain; as, the average annual rainfall of a region.
Relapsing: Marked by a relapse; falling back; tending to return to a former worse state.
Related: Allied by kindred; connected by blood or alliance, particularly by consanguinity; as, persons related in the first or second degree.
Rubrician: One skilled in, or tenaciously adhering to, the rubric or rubrics.
Reciprocalness: The quality or condition of being reciprocal; mutual return; alternateness.
Rum: A queer or odd person or thing; a country parson.
Revitalize: To restore vitality to; to bring back to life.
radiothorium: an earlier name for the thorium isotope thorium-228, given by its discoverer Otto Hahn.  It is a radioactive substance formed as one of series of products in the chain of radioactive decay of thorium.  Its immediate predecessor in the chain is Actinium-228, and it decays by alpha emission to radium-224 with a half-life of 1.91 years.  The name radiothorium was given prior to the full understanding of the nature of isotopes of elements.
&Verbar;Remiges: The quill feathers of the wings of a bird.
Repentance: The act of repenting, or the state of being penitent; sorrow for what one has done or omitted to do; especially, contrition for sin.
Retrusion: The act of retruding, or the state of being retruded.
Revolt: The act of revolting; an uprising against legitimate authority; especially, a renunciation of allegiance and subjection to a government; rebellion; as, the revolt of a province of the Roman empire.
Rubytail: A European gold wasp (Chrysis ignita) which has the under side of the abdomen bright red, and the other parts deep bluish green with a metallic luster. The larva is parasitic in the nests of other wasps and of bees.
Riches: That which makes one rich; an abundance of land, goods, money, or other property; wealth; opulence; affluence.
Roughly: In a rough manner; unevenly; harshly; rudely; severely; austerely.
Rarity: The quality or state of being rare; rareness; thinness; as, the rarity (contrasted with the density) of gases.
Renew: To become new, or as new; to grow or begin again.
Rhopalic: Applied to a line or verse in which each successive word has one more syllable than the preceding.
Rille: One of certain narrow, crooked valleys seen, by aid of the telescope, on the surface of the moon.
Regrate: To buy in large quantities, as corn, provisions, etc., at a market or fair, with the intention of selling the same again, in or near the same place, at a higher price, -- a practice which was formerly treated as a public offense.
Re\u00ebxamination: A repeated examination. See under Examination.
Recipiangle: An instrument with two arms that are pivoted together at one end, and a graduated arc, -- used by military engineers for measuring and laying off angles of fortifications.
Regrede: To go back; to retrograde, as the apsis of a planet's orbit.
Rubythroat: Any one of numerous species of humming birds belonging to Trochilus, Calypte, Stellula, and allies, in which the male has on the throat a brilliant patch of red feathers having metallic reflections; esp., the common humming bird of the Eastern United States (Trochilus colubris).
Regression: The act of passing back or returning; retrogression; retrogradation.
Restitute: That which is restored or offered in place of something; a substitute.
Retention: The act of retaining, or the state of being ratined.
Renowned: Famous; celebrated for great achievements, for distinguished qualities, or for grandeur; eminent; as, a renowned king.
Reportorial: Of or pertaining to a reporter or reporters; as, the reportorial staff of a newspaper.
Recruiter: One who, or that which, recruits.
Reprimand: To reprove severely; to reprehend; to chide for a fault; to consure formally.
Romanism: The tenets of the Church of Rome; the Roman Catholic religion.
Rarefy: To become less dense; to become thin and porous.
Rosied: Decorated with roses, or with the color of roses.
Rotten: Having rotted; putrid; decayed; as, a rotten apple; rotten meat.
Reductive: Tending to reduce; having the power or effect of reducing.
Regatta: Originally, a gondola race in Venice; now, a rowing or sailing race, or a series of such races.
Resplendence: The quality or state of being resplendent; brilliant luster; vivid brightness; splendor.
Rushlight: A rush candle, or its light; hence, a small, feeble light.
Roommate: One of two or more occupying the same room or rooms; one who shares the occupancy of a room or rooms; a chum.
Recumb: To lean; to recline; to repose.
Raising: The act of lifting, setting up, elevating, exalting, producing, or restoring to life.
Rescind: To cut off; to abrogate; to annul.
Rhyolite: A quartzose trachyte, an igneous rock often showing a fluidal structure.
Residuary: Consisting of residue; as, residuary matter; pertaining to the residue, or part remaining; as, the residuary advantage of an estate.
Rasorial: Of or pertaining to the Rasores, or gallinaceous birds, as the peacock, domestic fowl, partridge, quail, and the like.
Ramification: The process of branching, or the development of branches or offshoots from a stem; also, the mode of their arrangement.
Robbery: The act or practice of robbing; theft.
Reafforestation: The act or process of converting again into a forest.
Rakishness: The quality or state of being rakish.
Rover: One who practices robbery on the seas; a pirate.
Reference: The act of referring, or the state of being referred; as, reference to a chart for guidance.
Runic: Of or pertaining to a rune, to runes, or to the Norsemen; as, runic verses; runic letters; runic names; runic rhyme.
Re\u00ebntry: A second or new entry; as, a reëntry into public life.
Repullulation: The act of budding again; the state of having budded again.
Roque: A form of croquet modified for greater accuracy of play. The court has a wood border often faced with rubber, used as a cushion in bank shots. The balls are 31/4 in. in diameter, the cage (center arches or wickets) 33/8 in. wide, the other arches 31/2 in. wide.
Reliability: The state or quality of being reliable; reliableness.
Rapparee: A wild Irish plunderer, esp. one of the 17th century; -- so called from his carrying a half-pike, called a rapary.
Roscid: Containing, or consisting of, dew; dewy.
Rammish: Like a ram; hence, rank; lascivious.
Reconnoiter: To examine with the eye to make a preliminary examination or survey of; esp., to survey with a view to military or engineering operations.
Rainbow: A bow or arch exhibiting, in concentric bands, the several colors of the spectrum, and formed in the part of the hemisphere opposite to the sun by the refraction and reflection of the sun's rays in drops of falling rain.
Radically: In a radical manner; at, or from, the origin or root; fundamentally; as, a scheme or system radically wrong or defective.
Ruta-baga: A kind of turnip commonly with a large and long or ovoid yellowish root; a Swedish turnip. See Turnip.
Reperception: The act of perceiving again; a repeated perception of the same object.
Rescussee: The party in whose favor a rescue is made.
Reminiscent: One who is addicted to indulging, narrating, or recording reminiscences.
Reunite: To unite again; to join after separation or variance.
Reunion: A second union; union formed anew after separation, secession, or discord; as, a reunion of parts or particles of matter; a reunion of parties or sects.
Renter: To sew together so that the seam is scarcely visible; to sew up with skill and nicety; to finedraw.
Rile: To render turbid or muddy; to stir up; to roil.
Remand: The act of remanding; the order for recommitment.
Retrogradingly: By retrograding; so as to retrograde.
Rebukeful: Containing rebuke; of the nature of rebuke.
Royally: In a royal or kingly manner; like a king; as becomes a king.
Rackarock: A Sprengel explosive consisting of potassium chlorate and mono-nitrobenzene.
Refusal: The act of refusing; denial of anything demanded, solicited, or offered for acceptance.
Representer: One who shows, exhibits, or describes.
Raveling: The act of untwisting or of disentangling.
Rabbit: Any of the smaller species of the genus Lepus, especially the common European species (Lepus cuniculus), which is often kept as a pet, and has been introduced into many countries. It is remarkably prolific, and has become a pest in some parts of Australia and New Zealand.
Reordain: To ordain again, as when the first ordination is considered defective.
Roadster: A clumsy vessel that works its way from one anchorage to another by means of the tides.
Ranch: A tract of land used for grazing and the rearing of horses, cattle, or sheep. See Rancho, 2.
Rugged: Full of asperities on the surface; broken into sharp or irregular points, or otherwise uneven; not smooth; rough; as, a rugged mountain; a rugged road.
Rockery: A mound formed of fragments of rock, earth, etc., and set with plants.
Ravelin: A detached work with two embankments which make a salient angle. It is raised before the curtain on the counterscarp of the place. Formerly called demilune and half-moon.
Redeemableness: The quality or state of being redeemable; redeemability.
Reprobate: To disapprove with detestation or marks of extreme dislike; to condemn as unworthy; to disallow; to reject.
Rounceval: A giant; anything large; a kind of pea called also marrowfat.
Rind: To remove the rind of; to bark.
Rota: A species of zither, played like a guitar, used in the Middle Ages in church music; -- written also rotta.
Remonstrate: To present and urge reasons in opposition to an act, measure, or any course of proceedings; to expostulate; as, to remonstrate with a person regarding his habits; to remonstrate against proposed taxation.
Re-creation: A forming anew; a new creation or formation.
Reclaim: The act of reclaiming, or the state of being reclaimed; reclamation; recovery.
Resumptive: Taking back; resuming, or tending toward resumption; as, resumptive measures.
Rewin: To win again, or win back.
Ripply: Having ripples; as, ripply water; hence, resembling the sound of rippling water; as, ripply laughter; a ripply cove.
Rickstand: A flooring or framework on which a rick is made.
Reserve city: In the national banking system of the United States, any of certain cities in which the national banks are required (U. S. Rev. Stat. sec. 5191) to keep a larger reserve (25 per cent) than the minimum (15 per cent) required of all other banks. The banks in certain of the reserve cities (specifically called central reserve cities) are required to keep their reserve on hand in cash; banks in other reserve cities may keep half of their reserve as deposits in these banks (U. S. Rev. Stat. sec. 5195).
Relieve: To lift up; to raise again, as one who has fallen; to cause to rise.
Rubstone: A stone for scouring or rubbing; a whetstone; a rub.
&Verbar;Ramus: A branch; a projecting part or prominent process; a ramification.
Radiolarian: Of or pertaining to the Radiolaria.
Ripple: The fretting or dimpling of the surface, as of running water; little curling waves.
Resuscitate: To come to life again; to revive.
Reliquian: Of or pertaining to a relic or relics; of the nature of a relic.
Rung: A floor timber in a ship.
Redhibition: The annulling of a sale, and the return by the buyer of the article sold, on account of some defect.
Rejectment: Act of rejecting; matter rejected, or thrown away.
Regalement: The act of regaling; anything which regales; refreshment; entertainment.
Reparability: The quality or state of being reparable.
Remission: The act of remitting, surrendering, resigning, or giving up.
Renewer: One who, or that which, renews.
Radiated: Emitted, or sent forth, in rays or direct lines; as, radiated heat.
&Verbar;Rachialgia: A painful affection of the spine; especially, Pott's disease; also, formerly, lead colic.
Rhodammonium: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, rhodium and ammonia; -- said of certain complex compounds.
Razure: The act of erasing or effacing, or the state of being effaced; obliteration. See Rasure.
Repository: A place where things are or may be reposited, or laid up, for safety or preservation; a depository.
Reviving: Returning or restoring to life or vigor; reanimating.
Root: To plant and fix deeply in the earth, or as in the earth; to implant firmly; hence, to make deep or radical; to establish; -- used chiefly in the participle; as, rooted trees or forests; rooted dislike.
Retinoscopy: The study of the retina of the eye by means of the ophthalmoscope.
Roncador: Any one of several species of California sciænoid food fishes, especially Roncador Stearnsi, which is an excellent market fish, and the red roncador (Corvina saturna syn. Johnius saturna).
Recaptor: One who recaptures; one who takes a prize which had been previously taken.
Refectory: A room for refreshment; originally, a dining hall in monasteries or convents.
Reynard: An appelation applied after the manner of a proper name to the fox. Same as Renard.
Rentable: Capable of being rented, or suitable for renting.
Reverberation: The act of reverberating; especially, the act of reflecting light or heat, or reëchoing sound; as, the reverberation of rays from a mirror; the reverberation of rays from a mirror; the reverberation of voices; the reverberation of heat or flame in a furnace.
Rare: Not frequent; seldom met with or occurring; unusual; as, a rare event.
Ruff: A small freshwater European perch (Acerina vulgaris); -- called also pope, blacktail, and stone perch, or striped perch.
&Verbar;Radius vector: A straight line (or the length of such line) connecting any point, as of a curve, with a fixed point, or pole, round which the straight line turns, and to which it serves to refer the successive points of a curve, in a system of polar coördinates. See Coördinate, n.
Rostriform: Having the form of a beak.
Rougecroix: One of the four pursuivants of the English college of arms.
Rose-rial: A name of several English gold coins struck in different reigns and having having different values; a rose noble.
Rusher: One who strewed rushes on the floor at dances.
Rightness: Straightness; as, the rightness of a line.
Retene: A white crystalline hydrocarbon, polymeric with benzene. It is extracted from pine tar, and is also found in certain fossil resins.
&Verbar;Reichstag: The Diet, or House of Representatives, of the German empire (and of the Weimar Republic), which was composed of members elected for a term of three years by the direct vote of the people. This term is no longer (in 1997) applied to the German parliament. See also Bundesrath.
Repair: Restoration to a sound or good state after decay, waste, injury, or partial restruction; supply of loss; reparation; as, materials are collected for the repair of a church or of a city.
Recompilement: The act of recompiling; new compilation or digest; as, a recompilement of the laws.
Redactor: One who redacts; one who prepares matter for publication; an editor.
Redhibitory: Of or pertaining to redhibition; as, a redhibitory action or fault.
Reseizure: A second seizure; the act of seizing again.
Reflexity: The state or condition of being reflected.
Relation: The act of relating or telling; also, that which is related; recital; account; narration; narrative; as, the relation of historical events.
Relativistic: of, pertaining to, or in conformity with the theory of relativity; as, the relativistic increase of mass with velocity.
Ruthenious: Pertaining to, or containing, ruthenium; specifically, designating those compounds in  which it has a lower valence as contrasted with ruthenic compounds.
Roe, Richard: A fictious name for a party, real or fictious, to an act or proceeding. Other names were formerly similarly used, as John-a-Nokes, John o', or of the, Nokes, or Noakes, John-a-Stiles, etc.
Rosinweed: The compass plant. See under Compass.
Re-demption: The act of redeeming, or the state of being redeemed; repurchase; ransom; release; rescue; deliverance; as, the redemption of prisoners taken in war; the redemption of a ship and cargo.
Revilement: The act of reviling; also, contemptuous language; reproach; abuse.
&Verbar;Radiale: The bone or cartilage of the carpus which articulates with the radius and corresponds to the scaphoid bone in man.
Rudder: The mechanical appliance by means of which a vessel is guided or steered when in motion. It is a broad and flat blade made of wood or iron, with a long shank, and is fastened in an upright position, usually by one edge, to the sternpost of the vessel in such a way that it can be turned from side to side in the water by means of a tiller, wheel, or other attachment.
Rain-tight: So tight as to exclude rain; as, a rain-tight roof.
Rubbish: Of or pertaining to rubbish; of the quality of rubbish; trashy.
Renascible: Capable of being reproduced; ablle to spring again into being.
&Verbar;Rubus: A genus of rosaceous plants, including the raspberry and blackberry.
Rancor: The deepest malignity or spite; deep-seated enmity or malice; inveterate hatred.
Risible: Having the faculty or power of laughing; disposed to laugh.
Requin: The man-eater, or white shark (Carcharodon carcharias); -- so called on account of its causing requiems to be sung.
Rheocrat: A kind of motor speed controller permitting of very gradual variation in speed and of reverse. It is especially suitable for use with motor driven machine tools.
Ridder: One who, or that which, rids.
Revivification: Renewal of life; restoration of life; the act of recalling, or the state of being recalled, to life.
Revelator: One who makes a revelation; a revealer.
Repellence: The principle of repulsion; the quality or capacity of repelling; repulsion.
Ridiculous: Fitted to excite ridicule; absurd and laughable; unworthy of serious consideration; as, a ridiculous dress or behavior.
Rockiness: The state or quality of being rocky.
Rice-shell: Any one of numerous species of small white polished marine shells of the genus Olivella.
Retinic: Of or pertaining to resin; derived from resin; specifically, designating an acid found in certain fossil resins and hydrocarbons.
Re\u00ebngage: To engage a second time or again.
Radiotelegraphy: Telegraphy using the radiant energy of radio waves; wireless telegraphy; -- the term adopted for use by the Radiotelegraphic Convention of 1912.
&Verbar;Rathskeller: Orig., in Germany, the cellar or basement of the city hall, usually rented for use as a restaurant where beer is sold; hence, a beer saloon of the German type below the street level, where, usually, drinks are served only at tables and simple food may also be had; -- sometimes loosely used, in English, of what are essentially basement restaurants where liquors are served.
Rigger: One who rigs or dresses; one whose occupation is to fit the rigging of a ship.
Right-hand: Situated or being on the right; nearer the right hand than the left; as, the right-hand side, room, or road.
Radiotelephone: A wireless telephone, in which the signal is conveyed by radio waves.
&Verbar;Rhachilla: A branch of inflorescence; the zigzag axis on which the florets are arranged in the spikelets of grasses.
Rosemary: A labiate shrub (Rosmarinus officinalis) with narrow grayish leaves, growing native in the southern part of France, Spain, and Italy, also in Asia Minor and in China. It has a fragrant smell, and a warm, pungent, bitterish taste. It is used in cookery, perfumery, etc., and is an emblem of fidelity or constancy.
Relentless: Unmoved by appeals for sympathy or forgiveness; insensible to the distresses of others; destitute of tenderness; unrelenting; unyielding; unpitying; as, a prey to relentless despotism.
Replaceable: Capable or admitting of being put back into a place.
Russification: The act or process of Russifying, or the state of being Russified.
&Verbar;Rimau dahan: The clouded tiger cat (Felis marmorata) of Southern Asia and the East Indies.
R: R, the eighteenth letter of the English alphabet, is a vocal consonant.  It is sometimes called a semivowel, and a liquid. See Guide to Pronunciation, §§ 178, 179, and 250-254.
Rostellate: Having a rostellum, or small beak; terminating in a beak.
Racket: To make a confused noise or racket.
Revelous: Fond of festivity; given to merrymaking or reveling.
Radicalness: Quality or state of being radical.
Ridge: To form a ridge of; to furnish with a ridge or ridges; to make into a ridge or ridges.
Rosacic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid (called also lithic acid) found in certain red precipitates of urine. See Uric.
Rapid: The part of a river where the current moves with great swiftness, but without actual waterfall or cascade; sometimes called whitewater; -- usually used in the plural; as, the Lachine rapids in the St. Lawrence.
&Verbar;R\u00e9gime: Mode or system of rule or management; character of government, or of the prevailing social system.
Re\u00ebnforcement: The act of reënforcing, or the state of being reënforced.
Rial: A gold coin formerly current in England, of the value of ten shillings sterling in the reign of Henry VI., and of fifteen shillings in the reign of Elizabeth.
Rostrate: Having a process resembling the beak of a bird; beaked; rostellate.
Recoveree: The person against whom a judgment is obtained in common recovery.
Roadway: A road; especially, the part traveled by vehicles.
Ringlet: A small ring; a small circle; specifically, a fairy ring.
Ranker: One who ranks, or disposes in ranks; one who arranges.
Resolvableness: The quality of being resolvable; resolvability.
Righter: One who sets right; one who does justice or redresses wrong.
Recoct: To boil or cook again; hence, to make over; to vamp up; to reconstruct.
Rhizocarpous: Having perennial rootstocks or bulbs, but annual flowering stems; -- said of all perennial herbs.
Repulsive: Serving, or able, to repulse; repellent; as, a repulsive force.
Recoction: A second coction or preparation; a vamping up.
Reforestize: To convert again into a forest; to plant again with trees.
Resinic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, resin; as, the resinic acids.
Resell: To sell again; to sell what has been bought or sold; to retail.
Reabsorption: The act or process of reabsorbing.
Raptorial: Rapacious; living upon prey; -- said especially of certain birds.
Ruffler: One who ruffles; a swaggerer; a bully; a ruffian.
Realist: One who believes in realism; esp., one who maintains that generals, or the terms used to denote the genera and species of things, represent real existences, and are not mere names, as maintained by the nominalists.
Royalty: The state of being royal; the condition or quality of a royal person; kingship; kingly office; sovereignty.
Rushbuckler: A bullying and violent person; a braggart; a swashbuckler.
Represser: One who, or that which, represses.
Remonstrative: Having the character of a remonstrance; expressing remonstrance.
Resale: A sale at second hand, or at retail; also, a second sale.
Rummer: A large and tall glass, or drinking cup.
Roselite: A hydrous arsenite of cobalt, occuring in small red crystals, allied to erythrite.
&Verbar;Rouleau: A little roll; a roll of coins put up in paper, or something resembling such a roll.
Rosary: A bed of roses, or place where roses grow.
Recondensation: The act or process of recondensing.
Realism: As opposed to nominalism, the doctrine that genera and species are real things or entities, existing independently of our conceptions. According to realism the Universal exists ante rem (Plato), or in re (Aristotle).
Rule-monger: A stickler for rules; a slave of rules
Redemptorist: One of the Congregation of the Most Holy Redeemer, founded in Naples in 1732 by St. Alphonsus Maria de Liquori. It was introduced onto the United States in 1832 at Detroit. The Fathers of the Congregation devote themselves to preaching to the neglected, esp. in missions and retreats, and are forbidden by their rule to engage in the instruction of youth.
Redhorn: Any species of a tribe of butterflies (Fugacia) including the common yellow species and the cabbage butterflies. The antennæ are usually red.
Roost: To sit, rest, or sleep, as fowls on a pole, limb of a tree, etc.; to perch.
Rit: 3d pers. sing. pres. of Ride, contracted from rideth.
Ris: A bough or branch; a twig.
Rip: A rent made by ripping, esp. by a seam giving way; a tear; a place torn; laceration.
Revivificate: To revive; to recall or restore to life.
Revindicate: To vindicate again; to reclaim; to demand and take back.
Readjustment: A second adjustment; a new or different adjustment.
Recollection: The act of recollecting, or recalling to the memory; the operation by which objects are recalled to the memory, or ideas revived in the mind; reminiscence; remembrance.
Round-up: The act of collecting or gathering together scattered cattle by riding around them and driving them in.
Rig: To make free with; hence, to steal; to pilfer.
Rid: To save; to rescue; to deliver; -- with out of.
Rib: To furnish with ribs; to form with rising lines and channels; as, to rib cloth.
Restitution: The act of restoring anything to its rightful owner, or of making good, or of giving an equivalent for any loss, damage, or injury; indemnification.
&Verbar;Revers: A part turned or folded back so as to show the inside, or a piece put on in imitation of such a part, as the lapel of a coat.
Reillume: To light again; to cause to shine anew; to relume; to reillumine.
Rusk: A kind of light, soft bread made with yeast and eggs, often toasted or crisped in an oven; or, a kind of sweetened biscuit.
Refrication: A rubbing up afresh; a brightening.
Rush: A moving forward with rapidity and force or eagerness; a violent motion or course; as, a rush of troops; a rush of winds; a rush of water.
&Verbar;Reflet: Luster; special brilliancy of surface; -- used esp. in ceramics to denote the peculiar metallic brilliancy seen in lustered pottery such as majolica; as, silver reflet; gold reflet.
Recondite: Hidden from the mental or intellectual view; secret; abstruse; as, recondite causes of things.
&Verbar;Rhus: A genus of shrubs and small treets. See Sumac.
Rajahship: The office or dignity of a rajah.
Reply: That which is said, written, or done in answer to what is said, written, or done by another; an answer; a response.
Right-handed: Using the right hand habitually, or more easily than the left.
Redskin: A common appellation for a North American Indian; -- so called from the color of the skin.  It is now considered pejorative by some persons of North American Indian heritage.
-ric: A suffix signifying dominion, jurisdiction; as, bishopric, the district over which a bishop exercises authority.
Rhythmic: Pertaining to, or of the nature of, rhythm
Refix: To fix again or anew; to establish anew.
Repetend: That part of a circulating decimal which recurs continually, ad infinitum: -- sometimes indicated by a dot over the first and last figures; thus, in the circulating decimal .728328328 + (otherwise .7&dotted2_;8&dotted3_;), the repetend is 283.
Roughhew: To hew coarsely, without smoothing; as, to roughhew timber.
Rigolette: A woman's light scarflike head covering, usually knit or crocheted of wool.
Rise: To go up; to  ascend; to climb; as, to rise a hill.
&Verbar;Reddendum: A clause in a deed by which some new thing is reserved out of what had been granted before; the clause by which rent is reserved in a lease.
Refit: To obtain repairs or supplies; as, the fleet returned to refit.
Romajikai: An association, including both Japanese and Europeans, having for its object the changing of the Japanese method of writing by substituting Roman letters for Japanese characters.  Laso known as Hyojun Romajikai.
&Verbar;Rupia: An eruption upon the skin, consisting of vesicles with inflamed base and filled with serous, purulent, or bloody fluid, which dries up, forming a blackish crust.
Reversal: The act of reversing; the causing to move or face in an opposite direction, or to stand or lie in an inverted position; as, the reversal of a rotating wheel; the reversal of objects by a convex lens.
&Verbar;Repoussage: Art or process of hammering out or pressing thin metal from the reverse side: (1) in producing repoussé work; (2) in leveling up any part of an etched plate that has been worked so as to cause a depression.
Recency: The state or quality of being recent; newness; new state; late origin; lateness in time; freshness; as, the recency of a transaction, of a wound, etc.
Rut: To make a rut or ruts in; -- chiefly used as a past participle or a participial adj.; as, a rutted road.
Raphaelism: The principles of painting introduced by Raphael, the Italian painter.
Remunerative: Affording remuneration; as, a remunerative payment for services; a remunerative business.
Resider: One who resides in a place.
Round-backed: Having a round back or shoulders; round-shouldered.
Ritually: By rites, or by a particular rite.
Reproduction: The act or process of reproducing; the state of being reproduced
Ruse: An artifice; trick; stratagem; wile; fraud; deceit.
Rampion: A plant (Campanula Rapunculus) of the Bellflower family, with a tuberous esculent root; -- also called ramps.
Resurgent: One who rises again, as from the dead.
Resolute: One who is resolute; hence, a desperado.
&Verbar;Receptaculum: A receptacle; as, the receptaculum of the chyle.
Receptibility: The quality or state of being receptible; receivableness.
Reverent: Disposed to revere; impressed with reverence; submissive; humble; respectful; as, reverent disciples.
Retina: The delicate membrane by which the back part of the globe of the eye is lined, and in which the fibers of the optic nerve terminate. See Eye.
Runcinate: Pinnately cut with the lobes pointing downwards, as the leaf of the dandelion.
Redargue: To disprove; to refute; toconfute; to reprove; to convict.
Reprehend: To reprove or reprimand with a view of restraining, checking, or preventing; to make charge of fault against; to disapprove of; to chide; to blame; to censure.
Roentgen ray: the Anglicised spelling of Röntgen ray.  Same as X ray.
Rememoration: A recalling by the faculty of memory; remembrance.
Regularize: To cause to become regular; to regulate.
Retrovaccination: The inoculation of a cow with human vaccine virus.
Reconsideration: The act of reconsidering, or the state of being reconsidered; as, the reconsideration of a vote in a legislative body.
Rebuild: To build again, as something which has been demolished; to construct anew; as, to rebuild a house, a wall, a wharf, or a city.
Rhinoceros: Any pachyderm belonging to the genera Rhinoceros, Atelodus, and several allied genera of the family Rhinocerotidæ, of which several living, and many extinct, species are known. They are large and powerful, and usually have either one or two stout conical median horns on the snout.
Reforge: To forge again or anew; hence, to fashion or fabricate anew; to make over.
Rutilate: To shine; to emit rays of light.
Rubric: Colored in, or marked with, red; placed in rubrics.
Ratability: The quality or state of being ratable.
Rhomboganoid: A ganoid fish having rhombic enameled scales; one of the Rhomboganoidei.
Reprimer: A machine or implement for applying fresh primers to spent cartridge shells, so that the shells be used again.
Rhizanthous: Producing flowers from a rootstock, or apparently from a root.
Reveille: The beat of drum, or bugle blast, about break of day, to give notice that it is time for the soldiers to rise, and for the sentinels to forbear challenging.
Rensselaerite: A soft, compact variety of talc,, being an altered pyroxene. It is often worked in a lathe into inkstands and other articles.
Reconstruct: To construct again; to rebuild; to remodel; to form again or anew.
Rutile: A mineral usually of a reddish brown color, and brilliant metallic adamantine luster, occurring in tetragonal crystals. In composition it is titanium dioxide, like octahedrite and brookite.
Regimentals: The uniform worn by the officers and soldiers of a regiment; military dress; -- formerly used in the singular in the same sense.
Resinaceous: Having the quality of resin; resinous.
Refortification: A fortifying anew, or a second time.
Reduplication: The act of doubling, or the state of being doubled.
Ribbed: Furnished or formed with ribs; as, a ribbed cylinder; ribbed cloth.
Roral: Of or pertaining to dew; consisting of dew; dewy.
Ruralness: The quality or state of being rural.
Ripen: To cause to mature; to make ripe; as, the warm days ripened the corn.
Railroading: The construction of a railroad; the business of managing or operating a railroad.
&Verbar;Rigsdaler: A Danish coin worth about fifty-four cents. It was the former unit of value in Denmark.
Racket-tail: Any one of several species of humming birds of the genus Steganura, having two of the tail feathers very long and racket-shaped.
Refracted: Bent backward angularly, as if half-broken; as, a refracted stem or leaf.
Rheumy: Of or pertaining to rheum; abounding in, or causing, rheum; affected with rheum.
Rosolic: Pertaining to, or designating, a complex red dyestuff (called rosolic acid) which is analogous to rosaniline and aurin. It is produced by oxidizing a mixture of phenol and cresol, as a dark red amorphous mass, C20H16O3, which forms weak salts with bases, and stable ones with acids.  Called also methyl aurin, and, formerly, corallin.
Rocket: To rise straight up; said of birds; usually in the present participle or as an adjective.
&Verbar;Redif: A reserve force in the Turkish army, or a soldier of the reserve. See Army organization, above.
Receipt: To give a receipt, as for money paid.
Rosaceous: Of or pertaining to a natural order of plants (Rosaceæ) of which the rose is the type. It includes also the plums and cherries, meadowsweet, brambles, the strawberry, the hawthorn, applies, pears, service trees, and quinces.
Rhomb: An equilateral parallelogram, or quadrilateral figure whose sides are equal and the opposite sides parallel.  The angles may be unequal, two being obtuse and two acute, as in the cut, or the angles may be equal, in which case it is usually called a square.
Reprobation: The act of reprobating; the state of being reprobated; strong disapproval or censure.
Realgar: Arsenic sulphide, a mineral of a brilliant red color; red orpiment. It is also an artificial product.
&Verbar;Ramenta: Thin brownish chaffy scales upon the leaves or young shoots of some plants, especially upon the petioles and leaves of ferns.
Roseo-: A prefix (also used adjectively) signifying rose-red; specifically used to designate certain rose-red compounds (called roseo-cobaltic compounds) of cobalt with ammonia.  Cf. Luteo-.
Reservation: The act of reserving, or keeping back; concealment, or withholding from disclosure; reserve.
Ratiocinate: To reason, esp. deductively; to offer reason or argument.
&Verbar;Rudbeckia: A genus of composite plants, the coneflowers, consisting of perennial herbs with showy pedunculate heads, having a hemispherical involucre, sterile ray flowers, and a conical chaffy receptacle. There are about thirty species, exclusively North American. Rudbeckia hirta, the  black-eyed Susan, is a common weed in meadows.
Refluence: The quality of being refluent; a flowing back.
Responsible: Liable to respond; likely to be called upon to answer; accountable; answerable; amenable; as, a guardian is responsible to the court for his conduct in the office.
Revolving: Making a revolution or revolutions; rotating; -- used also figuratively of time, seasons, etc., depending on the revolution of the earth.
Raphany: A convulsive disease, attended with ravenous hunger, not uncommon in Sweden and Germany. It was so called because supposed to be caused by eating corn with which seeds of jointed charlock (Raphanus raphanistrum) had been mixed, but the condition is now known to be a form of ergotism.
Rococo: Of or pertaining to the style called rococo; like rococo; florid; fantastic.
Row: The act of rowing; excursion in a rowboat.
Refinery: The building and apparatus for refining or purifying, esp. metals and sugar.
Ringneck: Any one of several species of small plovers of the genus Ægialitis, having a ring around the neck. The ring is black in summer, but becomes brown or gray in winter.  The semipalmated plover (Ægialitis semipalmata) and the piping plover (Ægialitis meloda) are common North American species.  Called also ring plover, and ring-necked plover.
Reredos: A screen or partition wall behind an altar.
Regional: Of or pertaining to a particular region; sectional.
Revenge: The act of revenging; vengeance; retaliation; a returning of evil for evil.
Reasty: Rusty and rancid; -- applied to salt meat.
&Verbar;Rocaille: Artificial rockwork made of rough stones and cement, as for gardens.
Rideau: A small mound of earth; ground slightly elevated; a small ridge.
Redemptionary: One who is, or may be, redeemed.
Rubican: Colored a prevailing red, bay, or black, with flecks of white or gray especially on the flanks; -- said of horses.
Rioter: One who riots; a reveler; a roisterer.
Reflectingly: With reflection; also, with censure; reproachfully.
Rightfulness: The quality or state of being rightful; accordance with right and justice.
Residence: The act or fact of residing, abiding, or dwelling in a place for some continuance of time; as, the residence of an American in France or Italy for a year.
Rood: A representation in sculpture or in painting of the cross with Christ hanging on it.
Rune: A letter, or character, belonging to the written language of the ancient Norsemen, or Scandinavians; in a wider sense, applied to the letters of the ancient nations of Northern Europe in general.
Rebus: To mark or indicate by a rebus.
Rundlet: A small barrel of no certain dimensions. It may contain from 3 to 20 gallons, but it usually holds about 141/2 gallons.
&Verbar;Ribes: A genus of shrubs including gooseberries and currants of many kinds.
Recoiler: One who, or that which, recoils.
Rug: To pull roughly or hastily; to plunder; to spoil; to tear.
Rigoll: A musical instrument formerly in use, consisting of several sticks bound together, but separated by beads, and played with a stick with a ball at its end.
Redisseize: To disseize anew, or a second time.
Ribaldry: The talk of a ribald; low, vulgar language; indecency; obscenity; lewdness; -- now chiefly applied to indecent language, but formerly, as by Chaucer, also to indecent acts or conduct.
Reconvertible: Capable of being reconverted; convertible again to the original form or condition.
Registrant: One who registers; esp., one who , by virtue of securing an official registration, obtains a certain right or title of possession, as to a trade-mark.
Rareness: The state or quality of being rare.
Revival: The act of reviving, or the state of being revived.
Remise: A house for covered carriages; a chaise house.
&Verbar;Regidor: One of a body of officers charged with the government of Spanish municipalities, corresponding to the English alderman.
Rerefief: A fief held of a superior feudatory; a fief held by an under tenant.
Remiss: The act of being remiss; inefficiency; failure.
&Verbar;Rhynchophora: A group of Coleoptera having a snoutlike head; the snout beetles, curculios, or weevils.
Recommendable: Suitable to be recommended; worthy of praise; commendable.
Resonator: Anything which resounds; specifically, a vessel in the form of a cylinder open at one end, or a hollow ball of brass with two apertures, so contrived as to greatly intensify a musical tone by its resonance. It is used for the study and analysis of complex sounds.
Ravel: To become untwisted or unwoven; to be disentangled; to be relieved of intricacy.
Raven: To prey with rapacity; to be greedy; to show rapacity.
Rejuvenescence: A renewing of youth; the state of being or growing young again.
Righteousness: The quality or state of being righteous; holiness; purity; uprightness; rectitude.
Retaliatory: Tending to, or involving, retaliation; retaliative; as retaliatory measures.
Roomful: As much or many as a room will hold; as, a roomful of men.
Rachidian: Of or pertaining to the rachis; spinal; vertebral. Same as Rhachidian.
Roulette: To make short incisions in with a roulette; to separate by incisions made with a roulette; as, to roulette a sheet of postage stamps.
&Verbar;Rifacimento: A remaking or recasting; an adaptation, esp. of a literary work or musical composition.
&Verbar;Reis Effendi: A title formerly given to one of the chief Turkish officers of state.  He was chancellor of the empire, etc.
Rotunda: A round building; especially, one that is round both on the outside and inside, like the Pantheon at Rome. Less properly, but very commonly, used for a large round room; as, the rotunda of the Capitol at Washington.
Re-formation: The act of forming anew; a second forming in order; as, the reformation of a column of troops into a hollow square.
Re\u00ebxportation: The act of reëxporting, or of exporting an import.
Rogatory: Seeking information; authorized to examine witnesses or ascertain facts; as, a rogatory commission.
Ravening: Greedily devouring; rapacious; as, ravening wolves.
Reposition: The act of repositing; a laying up.
Refuse: Refused; rejected; hence; left as unworthy of acceptance; of no value; worthless.
Re\u00ebnthrone: To enthrone again; to replace on a throne.
Reducer: One who, or that which, reduces.
raglan sleeve: A sleeve joined to the body of a garment by a long slanting seam starting at the neck and continuing around the armhole.  Contrasted to a set-in sleeve.
&Verbar;Rubaiyat: Quatrians; as, the Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam. Sometimes in pl. construed as sing., a poem in such stanzas.
&Verbar;Rentier: One who has a fixed income, as from lands, stocks, or the like.
Riveting: The act of joining with rivets; the act of spreading out and clinching the end, as of a rivet, by beating or pressing.
Regimentally: In or by a regiment or regiments; as, troops classified regimentally.
&Verbar;Rivi\u00e8re: A necklace of diamonds or other precious stones, esp. one of several strings.
Rayless: Destitute of rays; hence, dark; not illuminated; blind; as, a rayless sky; rayless eyes.
Rhinal: Og or pertaining to the nose or olfactory organs.
Refulgent: Casting a bright light; radiant; brilliant; resplendent; shining; splendid; as, refulgent beams.
Rabbinic: The language or dialect of the rabbins; the later Hebrew.
Renovate: To make over again; to restore to freshness or vigor; to renew.
Razee: To cut down to a less number of decks, and thus to an inferior rate or class, as a ship; hence, to prune or abridge by cutting off or retrenching parts; as, to razee a book, or an article.
Romansch: The language of the Grisons in Switzerland, a corruption of the Latin.
Receptacular: Pertaining to the receptacle, or growing on it; as, the receptacular chaff or scales in the sunflower.
Responsive: That responds; ready or inclined to respond.
Redowa: A Bohemian dance of two kinds, one in triple time, like a waltz, the other in two-four time, like a polka. The former is most in use.
Reseat: To seat or set again, as on a chair, throne, etc.
Rostelliform: Having the form of a rostellum, or small beak.
Rootstock: A perennial underground stem, producing leafly s&unr_;ems or flower stems from year to year; a rhizome.
Rattlesnake: Any one of several species of venomous American snakes belonging to the genera Crotalus and Caudisona, or Sistrurus; sometimes also called rattler.  They have a series of horny interlocking joints at the end of the tail which make a sharp rattling sound when shaken.  The common rattlesnake of the Northern United States (Crotalus horridus), and the diamondback rattlesnake (also called diamondback rattler, and diamondback) of the South and East (Crotalus adamanteus) and West (Crotalus atrox), are the best known. See Illust. of Fang.
Repositor: An instrument employed for replacing a displaced organ or part.
Rite: The act of performing divine or solemn service, as established by law, precept, or custom; a formal act of religion or other solemn duty; a solemn observance; a ceremony; as, the rites of freemasonry.
Revealability: The quality or state of being revealable; revealableness.
Regrant: The act of granting back to a former proprietor.
Redwood: A gigantic coniferous tree (Sequoia sempervirens) of California, and its light and durable reddish timber. See Sequoia.
Relationship: The state of being related by kindred, affinity, or other alliance.
Radiomicrometer: A very sensitive modification or application of the thermopile, used for indicating minute changes of radiant heat, or temperature.
Reversible: Capable of being reversed; as, a chair or seat having a reversible back; a reversible judgment or sentence.
Ravener: One who, or that which, ravens or plunders.
Repeatedly: More than once; again and again; indefinitely.
Revivor: Revival of a suit which is abated by the death or marriage of any of the parties, -- done by a bill of revivor.
Recessive: A genetic trait determined by a recessive{2} allele; a trait not appearing in the phenotype unless both chromosomes of the organism have the same allele; also, an allele which is recessive{2}.
Riga fir: A species of pine (Pinus sylvestris), and its wood, which affords a valuable timber; -- called also Scotch pine, and red deal or yellow deal.  It grows in all parts of Europe, in the Caucasus, and in Siberia.
Relievable: Capable of being relieved; fitted to recieve relief.
Reconstructive: Reconstructing; tending to reconstruct; as, a reconstructive policy.
Red light: an electrically operated set of lights at a road intersection which has different lights visible to traffic from different directions, designed to control vehicle traffic through the intersection.  Each set of lights typically has a colored red light and also green and amber lights; the color of the light which is lighted at any one time changes automatically to control the flow of traffic through the intersection, allowing flow from different directions in alternating succession.  Also called traffic light, traffic signal or stop light.  When the red light is illuminated the signal means to stop; green means to go; and amber means to stop or procede through the intersection with caution.  In simple intersections of two roads, a red light visible to traffic on one road will usually be accompanied by a green light visible to traffic on the intersecting road.  In some locations the lights may be set to be illuminated in other sequences or combinations; a blinking red light is typically equivalent to a “stop” sign, and a blinking amber light typically means “procede with caution”.
Resolvedly: So as to resolve or clear up difficulties; clearly.
Rascallion: A low, mean wretch; a rogue; same as rascal, n.. 2; now disused, replaced by rapscalion.
Reconnaissance: The act of reconnoitering; preliminary examination or survey.
Redcoat: One who wears a red coat; specifically, a red-coated British soldier.
Retired: Private; secluded; quiet; as, a retired life; a person of retired habits.
Ringent: Having the lips widely separated and gaping like an open mouth; as a ringent bilabiate corolla.
Rumseller: One who sells rum; one who deals in intoxicating liquors; especially, one who sells spirituous beverages at retail.
Ruridecanal: Of or pertaining to a rural dean; as, a ruridecanal district; the ruridecanal intellect.
Re-store: To store again; as, the goods taken out were re-stored.
Reviviscent: Able or disposed to revive; reviving.
Runagate: A fugitive; a vagabond; an apostate; a renegade. See Renegade.
Redolent: Diffusing odor or fragrance; spreading sweet scent; scented; odorous; smelling; -- usually followed by of.
R\u00f4le: A part, or character, performed by an actor in a drama; hence, a part of function taken or assumed by any one; as, he has now taken the rôle of philanthropist.
Rackett: An old wind instrument of the double bassoon kind, having ventages but not keys.
&Verbar;R\u00e9gie: Direct management of public finance or public works by agents of the government for government account; -- opposed to the contract system.
Rude: Characterized by roughness; umpolished; raw; lacking delicacy or refinement; coarse.
Ratifier: One who, or that which, ratifies; a confirmer.
Re-search: To search again; to examine anew.
Ranunculaceous: Of or pertaining to a natural order of plants (Ranunculaceæ), of which the buttercup is the type, and which includes also the virgin's bower, the monkshood, larkspur, anemone, meadow rue, and peony.
Roundness: The quality or state of being round in shape; as, the roundness of the globe, of the orb of the sun, of a ball, of a bowl, a column, etc.
Regularly: In a regular manner; in uniform order; methodically; in due order or time.
&Verbar;Retineum: That part of the eye of an invertebrate which corresponds in function with the retina of a vertebrate.
&Verbar;Rebozo: A kind of mantilla worn by women over the head and shoulders, and sometimes over part of the face.
Rendible: Capable, or admitting, of being rendered.
Rufterhood: A kind of hood for a hawk.
Rajah: A native prince or king; also, a landholder or person of importance in the agricultural districts.
Reforestization: The act or process of reforestizing.
Refrain: The burden of a song; a phrase or verse which recurs at the end of each of the separate stanzas or divisions of a poetic composition.
Regency: The office of ruler; rule; authority; government.
Rudd: A fresh-water European fish of the Carp family (Leuciscus erythrophthalmus). It is about the size and shape of the roach, but it has the dorsal fin farther back, a stouter body, and red irises. Called also redeye, roud, finscale, and shallow.  A blue variety is called azurine, or blue roach.
Respire: To breathe in and out; to inspire and expire,, as air; to breathe.
&Verbar;Razzia: A plundering and destructive incursion; a foray; a raid.
Reserve: The act of reserving, or keeping back; reservation.
Redressless: Not having redress; such as can not be redressed; irremediable.
Rosewood: A valuable cabinet wood of a dark red color, streaked and variegated with black, obtained from several tropical leguminous trees of the genera Dalbergia and Machærium. The finest kind is from Brazil, and is said to be from the Dalbergia nigra.
Riotry: The act or practice of rioting; riot.
Rocky: Full of, or abounding in, rocks; consisting of rocks; as, a rocky mountain; a rocky shore.
Repercuss: To drive or beat back; hence, to reflect; to reverberate.
Redly: In a red manner; with redness.
Reefing: The process of taking in a reef.
Reformado: A monk of a reformed order.
Remastication: The act of masticating or chewing again or repeatedly.
&Verbar;Rhopalocera: A division of Lepidoptera including all the butterflies. They differ from other Lepidoptera in having club-shaped antennæ.
Researcher: One who conducts research.  In the field of scientific research, also called an investigator or scientist.
Releasement: The act of releasing, as from confinement or obligation.
Re\u00ebmbark: To put, or go, on board a vessel again; to embark again.
&Verbar;Rhonchus: An adventitious whistling or snoring sound heard on auscultation of the chest when the air channels are partially obstructed. By some writers the term rhonchus is used as equivalent to râle in its widest sense. See Râle.
Razor-backed: Having a sharp, lean, or thin back; as, a razor-backed hog, perch, etc.
Respecting: With regard or relation to; regarding; concerning; as, respecting his conduct there is but one opinion.
Rationalize: To use, and rely on, reason in forming a theory, belief, etc., especially in matters of religion: to accord with the principles of rationalism.
Restrengthen: To strengthen again; to fortify anew.
Rayon: A synthetic fiber, made of thin filaments of regenerated cellulose, extruded from a solution of viscose.  Called also viscose fiber and viscose rayon fiber.
Regenerative: Of or pertaining to regeneration; tending to regenerate; as, regenerative influences.
Ransack: The act of ransacking, or state of being ransacked; pillage.
Revestiary: The apartment, in a church or temple, where the vestments, etc., are kept; -- now contracted into vestry.
Resuscitator: One who, or that which, resuscitates.
Rectorial: Pertaining to a rector or a rectory; rectoral.
&Verbar;Reiter: A German cavalry soldier of the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries.
Resinously: By means, or in the manner, of resin.
Robing: The act of putting on a robe.
Rasse: A carnivore (Viverricula Mallaccensis) allied to the civet but smaller, native of China and the East Indies. It furnishes a perfume resembling that of the civet, which is highly prized by the Javanese. Called also Malacca weasel, and lesser civet.
&Verbar;Residencia: In Spanish countries, a court or trial held, sometimes as long as six months, by a newly elected official, as the governor of a province, to examine into the conduct of a predecessor.
Rolliche: A kind of sausage, made in a bag of tripe, sliced and fried, famous among the Dutch of New Amsterdam and still known, esp. in New Jersey.
Ruinous: Causing, or tending to cause, ruin; destructive; baneful; pernicious; as, a ruinous project.
Redemise: The transfer of an estate back to the person who demised it; reconveyance; as, the demise and redemise of an estate. See under Demise.
Reparation: The act of renewing, restoring, etc., or the state of being renewed or repaired; as, the reparation of a bridge or of a highway; -- in this sense, repair is oftener used.
Rafter: To make into rafters, as timber.
Rhinoplastic: Of or pertaining to rhinoplasty; as, a rhinoplastic operation.
Roughsetter: A mason who builds rough stonework.
Rhemish: Of or pertaining to Rheimis, or Reima, in France.
&Verbar;Regma: A kind of dry fruit, consisting of three or more cells, each which at length breaks open at the inner angle.
Repentant: One who repents, especially one who repents of sin; a penitent.
Reformative: Forming again; having the quality of renewing form; reformatory.
Running: The act of one who, or of that which runs; as, the running was slow.
&Verbar;Rhinencephalon: The division of the brain in front of the prosencephalon, consisting of the two olfactory lobes from which the olfactory nerves arise.
Rhipipter: One of the Rhipiptera, a group of insects having wings which fold like a fan; a strepsipter.
Rampire: To fortify with a rampire; to form into a rampire.
Redthroat: A small Australian singing bird (Phyrrholæmus brunneus). The upper parts are brown, the center of the throat red.
Rhinoscope: A small mirror for use in rhinoscopy.
Respiration: The act of respiring or breathing again, or catching one's breath.
Recognizor: One who enters into a recognizance.
Roin: A scab; a scurf, or scurfy spot.
Rhetian: Pertaining to the ancient Rhæti, or Rhætians, or to Rhætia, their country; as, the Rhetian Alps, now the country of Tyrol and the Grisons.
Roseate: Full of roses; rosy; as, roseate bowers.
Resentingly: With deep sense or strong perception.
Rabbet: To cut a rabbet in; to furnish with a rabbet.
Recognitor: One of a jury impaneled on an assize.
Regratiatory: A returning or giving of thanks.
Rhinoscopy: The examination or study of the soft palate, posterior nares, etc., by means of a laryngoscopic mirror introduced into the pharynx.
Roughdraw: To draw or delineate rapidly and by way of a first sketch.
radioactivity: a form of instability which is a property of the atomic nuclei of certain isotopes, which causes a spontaneous change in the structure of the nucleus, accompanied by emission of energetic radiation.  The radiation emitted is usually sufficient to cause ionization in matter through which it passes, and is therefore called ionizing radiation.  The radiation emitted by most radioactive substances is one of three types: alpha rays, beta rays, or gamma rays.  Some chemical elements have no stable isotopes, and these are referred to as radioactive elements, and the element itself is said to possess radioactivity.
Reflexive: Bending or turned backward; reflective; having respect to something past.
Radial tire: a motor vehicle tire in which the cords run at right angles to the plane of the tire (considered as a disk).
Reimpression: A second or repeated impression; a reprint.
Radical: A primitive word; a radix, root, or simple, underived, uncompounded word; an etymon.
Ryal: See Rial, an old English coin.
Rubian: One of several color-producing glycosides found in madder root.
Reduce: To bring or lead back to any former place or condition.
Reflorescence: A blossoming anew of a plant after it has apparently ceased blossoming for the season.
Rebukable: Worthy of rebuke or reprehension; reprehensible.
rofecoxib: A chemical substance (C17H14O4S, molecular weight 314.36) used in medicine as an analgesic to alleviate pain and inflammation; it is a synthetic compound, and is marketed by Merck & Co. under the trade name Vioxx, in tablets giving dosages of 12.5 or 25 milligrams.  It is classed as a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID).  Chemically, it is 4-[4-(methylsulfony)phenyl]-3-phenyl-2(5H) furanone.  Its chemical structure contains two phenyl rings and a furanone ring.  It is believed to act by inhibition of prostaglandin biosynthesis, through inhibition of the enzyme cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2); unlike aspirin, it does not inhibit cyclooxygenase-1.
Revocatory: Of or pertaining to revocation; tending to, or involving, a revocation; revoking; recalling.
Roger: A black flag with white skull and crossbones, formerly used by pirates; -- called also Jolly Roger and pirate flag.
Runaway: Running away; fleeing from danger, duty, restraint, etc.; as, runaway soldiers; a runaway horse.
Remasticate: To chew or masticate again; to chew over and over, as the cud.
Resemblance: The quality or state of resembling; likeness; similitude; similarity.
Ragamuffin: A paltry or disreputable fellow; a mean wretch.
Refute: To disprove and overthrow by argument, evidence, or countervailing proof; to prove to be false or erroneous; to confute; as, to refute arguments; to refute testimony; to refute opinions or theories; to refute a disputant.
Raddle: To mark or paint with, or as with, raddle.
Retinue: The body of retainers who follow a prince or other distinguished person; a train of attendants; a suite.
&Verbar;Ronin: In Japan, under the feudal system, a samurai who had renounced his clan or who had been discharged or ostracized and had become a wanderer without a lord; an outcast; an outlaw.
Raceabout: A small sloop-rigged racing yacht carrying about six hundred square feet of sail, distinguished from a knockabout by having a short bowsprit.
Ravissant: In a half-raised position, as if about to spring on prey.
&Verbar;Ratit\u00e6: An order of birds in which the wings are small, rudimentary, or absent, and the breastbone is destitute of a keel. The ostrich, emu, moa, and apteryx are examples.
Reship: To engage one's self again for service on board of a vessel after having been discharged.
Raceme: A flower cluster with an elongated axis and many one-flowered lateral pedicels, as in the currant and chokecherry.
Raffle: To dispose of by means of a raffle; -- often followed by off; as, to raffle off a horse.
Rufiopin: A yellowish red crystalline substance related to anthracene, and obtained from opianic acid.
&Verbar;Rictus: The gape of the mouth, as of birds; -- often resricted to the corners of the mouth.
Razorable: Ready for the razor; fit to be shaved.
Roquefort cheese: A highly flavored blue-molded cheese, made at Roquefort, department of Aveyron, France. It is made from milk of ewes, sometimes with cow's milk added, and is cured in caves. Improperly, a cheese made in imitation of it.
Rock shaft: A shaft that oscillates on its journals, instead of revolving, -- usually carrying levers by means of which it receives and communicates reciprocating motion, as in the valve gear of some steam engines; -- called also rocker, rocking shaft, and way shaft.
Romeward: Tending or directed toward Rome, or toward the Roman Catholic Church.
Richesse: Wealth; riches. See the Note under Riches.
Renewal: The act of renewing, or the state of being renewed; as, the renewal of a treaty.
Regive: To give again; to give back.
Recantation: The act of recanting; a declaration that contradicts a former one; that which is thus asserted in contradiction; retraction.
Refractometer: A contrivance for exhibiting and measuring the refraction of light.
Rectovaginal: Of or pertaining to both the rectum and the vagina.
Rubricate: To mark or distinguished with red; to arrange as in a rubric; to establish in a settled and unchangeable form.
Rabblement: A tumultuous crowd of low people; a rabble.
Redargutory: Pertaining to, or containing, redargution; refutatory.
Recapitulation: The act of recapitulating; a summary, or concise statement or enumeration, of the principal points, facts, or statements, in a preceding discourse, argument, or essay.
Repealer: One who repeals; one who seeks a repeal; specifically, an advocate for the repeal of the Articles of Union between Great Britain and Ireland.
Recruit: A supply of anything wasted or exhausted; a reënforcement.
Rouser: One who, or that which, rouses.
Refractorily: In a refractory manner; perversely; obstinately.
Rattan: One of the long slender flexible stems of several species of palms of the genus Calamus, mostly East Indian, though some are African and Australian. They are exceedingly tough, and are used for walking sticks, wickerwork, chairs and seats of chairs, cords and cordage, and many other purposes.
Rising: The act of one who, or that which, rises (in any sense).
Research: Diligent inquiry or examination in seeking facts or principles; laborious or continued search after truth; as, researches of human wisdom; to research a topic in the library; medical research.
Rutilian: Any species of lamellicorn beetles belonging to Rutila and allied genera, as the spotted grapevine beetle (Pelidnota punctata).
Rang: imp. of Ring, v. t. & i.
Recess: A decree of the imperial diet of the old German empire.
Rudiment: To furnish with first principles or rules; to insrtuct in the rudiments.
Recognize: To enter an obligation of record before a proper tribunal; as, A B recognized in the sum of twenty dollars.
&Verbar;Rete: A net or network; a plexus; particularly, a network of blood vessels or nerves, or a part resembling a network.
Rank: To be ranged; to be set or disposed, as in a particular degree, class, order, or division.
Repugn: To fight against; to oppose; to resist.
Rant: High-sounding language, without importance or dignity of thought; boisterous, empty declamation; bombast; as, the rant of fanatics.
Repartotion: Another, or an additional, separation into parts.
Royalization: The act of making loyal to a king.
Right-hearted: Having a right heart or disposition.
Residue: That which remains after a part is taken, separated, removed, or designated; remnant; remainder.
Riden: imp. pl. & p. p. of Ride.
Rely: To rest with confidence, as when fully satisfied of the veracity, integrity, or ability of persons, or of the certainty of facts or of evidence; to have confidence; to trust; to depend; -- with on, formerly also with in.
Resentful: Inclined to resent; easily provoked to anger; irritable.
Repealability: The quality or state of being repealable.
Rigging: Dress; tackle; especially (Naut.), the ropes, chains, etc., that support the masts and spars of a vessel, and serve as purchases for adjusting the sails, etc. See Illustr. of Ship and Sails.
Rep: Formed with a surface closely corded, or ribbed transversely; -- applied to textile fabrics of silk or wool; as, rep silk.
Ramtil: A tropical African asteraceous shrub (Guizotia abyssinica) cultivated for its seeds (called ramtil seeds or niger seeds) which yield a valuable oil used for food and as an illuminant.
Ret: To prepare for use, as flax, by separating the fibers from the woody part by process of soaking, macerating, and other treatment.
Romance: To write or tell romances; to indulge in extravagant stories.
Rhinolophine: Like or pertaining to the rhinolophids, or horseshoe bats.
Revulsive: That which causes revulsion; specifically (Med.), a revulsive remedy or agent.
Rei: A portuguese money of account, in value about one tenth of a cent.
Rick: To heap up in ricks, as hay, etc.
Reflective: Throwing back images; as, a reflective mirror.
Rice: A well-known cereal grass (Oryza sativa) and its seed.  This plant is extensively cultivated in warm climates, and the grain forms a large portion of the food of the inhabitants. In America it grows chiefly on low, moist land, which can be overflowed.
Red: The color of blood, or of that part of the spectrum farthest from violet, or a tint resembling these.
Ree: To riddle; to sift; to separate or throw off.
&Verbar;Roulade: A smoothly running passage of short notes (as semiquavers, or sixteenths) uniformly grouped, sung upon one long syllable, as in Handel's oratorios.
Reportable: Capable or admitting of being reported.
Ringbolt: An eyebolt having a ring through the eye.
Romanticist: One who advocates romanticism in modern literature.
Roundly: In a round form or manner.
Rutic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, rue (Ruta); as, rutic acid, now commonly called capric acid.
Renewable: Capable of being renewed; as, a lease renewable at pleasure.
Resend: To send again; as, to resend a message.
Russ: Of or pertaining to the Russians.
Raphe: A line, ridge, furrow, or band of fibers, especially in the median line; as, the raphe of the tongue.
Resurrectionist: One who steals bodies from the grave, as for dissection.
Roorback: A defamatory forgery or falsehood published for purposes of political intrigue.
Rabbinically: In a rabbinical manner; after the manner of the rabbins.
Rabat: A polishing material made of potter's clay that has failed in baking.
Resurrect: To take from the grave; to disinter.
