Radioscopy: Direct observation of objects opaque to light by means of some other form of radiant energy, as x-rays.
Reckoning: The act of one who reckons, counts, or computes; the result of reckoning or counting; calculation.
Reproach: To come back to, or come home to, as a matter of blame; to bring shame or disgrace upon; to disgrace.
Renovation: The act or process of renovating; the state of being renovated or renewed.
Roadstead: An anchorage off shore. Same as Road, 4.
Remote: Removed to a distance; not near; far away; distant; -- said in respect to time or to place; as, remote ages; remote lands.
Republicanism: A republican form or system of government; the principles or theory of republican government.
Re-let: To let anew, as a house.
Rigmarole: Consisting of rigmarole; frivolous; nonsensical; foolish.
Radix: A primitive word, from which spring other words; a radical; a root; an etymon.
&Verbar;Risqu\u00e9: Hazardous; risky; esp., fig., verging upon impropriety; dangerously close to, or suggestive of, what is indecent or of doubtful morality; as, a risqué story.
Reservee: One to, or for, whom anything is reserved; -- contrasted with reservor.
Rakish: Having a saucy appearance indicative of speed and dash.
Repulse: To repel; to beat or drive back; as, to repulse an assault; to repulse the enemy.
Rockrose: A name given to any species of the genus Helianthemum, low shrubs or herbs with yellow flowers, especially the European Helianthemum vulgare and the American frostweed, Helianthemum Canadense.
Racketer: One who makes, or engages in, a racket.
Rhizine: A rootlike filament or hair growing from the stems of mosses or on lichens; a rhizoid.
Recoveror: The demandant in a common recovery after judgment.
Rhodochrosite: Manganese carbonate, a rose-red mineral sometimes occuring crystallized, but generally massive with rhombohedral cleavage like calcite; -- called also dialogite.
Revest: To take effect or vest again, as a title; to revert to former owner; as, the title or right revests in A after alienation.
Redirect: Applied to the examination of a witness, by the party calling him, after the cross-examination.
Refresher: One who, or that which, refreshes.
recuse: To withdraw oneself from serving as a judge or other decision-maker in order to avoid a real or apparent conflict of interest; -- often used with the reflexive; as, the judge recused himself due to a financial interest in the matter.
Reluctate: To struggle against anything; to resist; to oppose.
Redan: A work having two parapets whose faces unite so as to form a salient angle toward the enemy.
Roborate: To give strength or support to; to confirm.
Revolting: Causing abhorrence mixed with disgust; exciting extreme repugnance; loathsome; as, revolting cruelty.
Refractiveness: The quality or condition of being refractive.
Rabble: To insult, or assault, by a mob; to mob; as, to rabble a curate.
Recto: The right-hand page; -- opposed to verso.
Retro-: A prefix or combining form signifying backward, back; as, retroact, to act backward; retrospect, a looking back.
Retistene: A white crystalline hydrocarbon produced indirectly from retene.
Roofless: Having no roof; as, a roofless house.
Red-gum: An eruption of red pimples upon the face, neck, and arms, in early infancy; tooth rash; strophulus.
Recorporification: The act of investing again with a body; the state of being furnished anew with a body.
Rhinopome: Any old-world bat of the genus Rhinopoma. The rhinopomes have a long tail extending beyond the web, and inhabit caves and tombs.
Recalcitrate: To kick back; to kick against anything; hence, to express repugnance or opposition.
Reversed: Turned side for side, or end for end; changed to the contrary;
Router: A plane made like a spokeshave, for working the inside edges of circular sashes.
Regularity: The condition or quality of being regular; as, regularity of outline; the regularity of motion.
Rememberable: Capable or worthy of being remembered.
Roscoelite: A green micaceous mineral occurring in minute scales. It is essentially a silicate of aluminia and potash containing vanadium.
Ragpicker: One who gets a living by picking up rags and refuse things in the streets.
Reliever: One who, or that which, relieves.
Rotal: Relating to wheels or to rotary motion; rotary.
Respectful: Marked or characterized by respect; as, respectful deportment.
Rationalistic: Belonging to, or in accordance with, the principles of rationalism.
Registrar: One who registers; a recorder; a keeper of records; as, a registrar of births, deaths, and marriages. See Register, n., 3.
Radian: An arc of a circle which is equal to the radius, or the angle measured by such an arc.
Radial: Of or pertaining to a radius or ray; consisting of, or like, radii or rays; radiated; as, (Bot.) radial projections; (Zoöl.) radial vessels or canals; (Anat.) the radial artery.
Resaw: To saw again; specifically, to saw a balk, or a timber, which has already been squared, into dimension lumber, as joists, boards, etc.
Readvertency: The act of adverting to again, or of reviewing.
Rhabdoc\u0153lous: Of or pertaining to the Rhabdocœla.
Recession: The act of ceding back; restoration; repeated cession; as, the recession of conquered territory to its former sovereign.
Russet: A russet color; a pigment of a russet color.
Reliction: A leaving dry; a recession of the sea or other water, leaving dry land; land left uncovered by such recession.
Reprehensible: Worthy of reprehension; culpable; censurable; blamable.
Requiem: A mass said or sung for the repose of a departed soul.
Ravager: One who, or that which, ravages or lays waste; spoiler.
Rumicin: A yellow crystalline substance found in the root of yellow dock (Rumex crispus) and identical with chrysophanic acid.
Relative: One who, or that which, relates to, or is considered in its relation to, something else; a relative object or term; one of two object or term; one of two objects directly connected by any relation.
Raiffeisen: Designating, or pertaining to, a form of coöperative bank founded among the German agrarian population by Friedrich Wilhelm Raiffeisen (1818-88); as, Raiffeisen banks, the Raiffeisen system, etc. The banks are unlimited-liability institutions making small loans at a low rate of interest, for a designated purpose, to worthy members only.
Resignee: One to whom anything is resigned, or in whose favor a resignation is made.
Retrograde: To go in a retrograde direction; to move, or appear to move, backward, as a planet.
&Verbar;Rai\u00e6: The order of elasmobranch fishes which includes the sawfishes, skates, and rays; -- called also Rajæ, and Rajii.
Reliance: The act of relying, or the condition or quality of being reliant; dependence; confidence; trust; repose of mind upon what is deemed sufficient support or authority.
Religion: The outward act or form by which men indicate their recognition of the existence of a god or of gods having power over their destiny, to whom obedience, service, and honor are due; the feeling or expression of human love, fear, or awe of some superhuman and overruling power, whether by profession of belief, by observance of rites and ceremonies, or by the conduct of life; a system of faith and worship; a manifestation of piety; as, ethical religions; monotheistic religions; natural religion; revealed religion; the religion of the Jews; the religion of idol worshipers.
Racktail: An arm attached to a swinging notched arc or rack, to let off the striking mechanism of a repeating clock.
Regal: A small portable organ, played with one hand, the bellows being worked with the other, -- used in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.
Reviviscence: The act of reviving, or the state of being revived; renewal of life.
Reillumine: To illumine again or anew; to reillume.
Rogation: The demand, by the consuls or tribunes, of a law to be passed by the people; a proposed law or decree.
Refection: Refreshment after hunger or fatigue; a repast; a lunch.
Ruffle: That which is ruffled; specifically, a strip of lace, cambric, or other fine cloth, plaited or gathered on one edge or in the middle, and used as a trimming; a frill.
Reconvert: A person who has been reconverted.
Revengeable: Capable of being revenged; as, revengeable wrong.
Reagent: A substance capable of producing with another a reaction, especially when employed to detect the presence of other bodies; a test.
Reassurance: Assurance or confirmation renewed or repeated.
Rounce: The handle by which the bed of a hand press, holding the form of type, etc., is run in under the platen and out again; -- sometimes applied to the whole apparatus by which the form is moved under the platen.
Radio-: A combining form indicating connection with, or relation to, a radius or ray; specifically (Anat.), with the radius of the forearm; as, radio-ulnar, radio-muscular, radio-carpal.
Rabate: To recover to the fist, as a hawk.
Rostrum: The beak or head of a ship.
Rhachiodont: Having gular teeth formed by a peculiar modification of the inferior spines of some of the vertebræ, as certain South African snakes (Dasypeltis) which swallow birds' eggs and use these gular teeth to crush them.
Rower: One who rows with an oar.
Rhizogen: One of a proposed class of flowering plants growning on the roots of other plants and destitute of green foliage.
Rhinocerial: Of or pertaining to the rhinoceros; resembling the rhinoceros, or his horn.
Reclusion: A state of retirement from the world; seclusion.
Riffle: A trough or sluice having cleats, grooves, or steps across the bottom for holding quicksilver and catching particles of gold when auriferous earth is washed; also, one of the cleats, grooves, or steps in such a trough. Also called ripple.
Ringworm: A contagious affection of the skin due to the presence of a vegetable parasite, and forming ring-shaped discolored patches covered with vesicles or powdery scales. It occurs either on the body, the face, or the scalp.  Different varieties are distinguished as Tinea circinata, Tinea tonsurans, etc., but all are caused by the same parasite (a species of Trichophyton).
Redbud: A small ornamental leguminous tree of the American species of the genus Cercis. See Judas tree, under Judas.
Rink: The smooth and level extent of ice marked off for the game of curling.
Redmouth: Any one of several species of marine food fishes of the genus Diabasis, or Hæmulon, of the Southern United States, having the inside of the mouth bright red. Called also flannelmouth, and grunt.
Repeater: One who, or that which, repeats.
Recension: The act of reviewing or revising; review; examination; enumeration.
Readeption: A regaining; recovery of something lost.
Ramsted: A yellow-flowered weed; -- so named from a Mr. Ramsted who introduced it into Pennsylvania. See Toad flax. Called also Ramsted weed.
Rumbling: a. & n. from Rumble, v. i.
Registration: The act of registering; registry; enrollment.
Rheumatismoid: Of or resembling rheum or rheumatism.
Reedless: Destitute of reeds; as, reedless banks.
Rainy: Abounding with rain; wet; showery; as, rainy weather; a rainy day or season.
Ruttish: Inclined to rut; lustful; libidinous; salacious.
Rabbinism: A rabbinic expression or phraseology; a peculiarity of the language of the rabbins.
Rocker: One who rocks; specifically, one who rocks a cradle.
Rim-fire: Having the percussion fulminate in a rim surrounding the base, distinguished from  center-fire; -- said of cartridges; also, using rim-fire cartridges; as, a rim-fire gun. Such cartridges are now little used.
Rectorate: The office, rank, or station of a rector; rectorship.
Rout cake: A kind of rich sweet cake made for routs, or evening parties.
Reascension: The act of reascending; a remounting.
Relevance: The quality or state of being relevant; pertinency; applicability.
Remittance: The act of transmitting money, bills, or the like, esp. to a distant place, as in satisfaction of a demand, or in discharge of an obligation.
Randing: The act or process of making and applying rands for shoes.
Rookery: The breeding place of a colony of rooks; also, the birds themselves.
Rainless: Destitute of rain; as, a rainless region.
Roundfish: Any ordinary market fish, exclusive of flounders, sole, halibut, and other flatfishes.
Rabbinist: One among the Jews who adhered to the Talmud and the traditions of the rabbins, in opposition to the Karaites, who rejected the traditions.
Rhaphe: The continuation of the seed stalk along the side of an anatropous ovule or seed, forming a ridge or seam.
Russophobia: Morbid dread of Russia or of Russian influence.
Ragman: A document having many names or numerous seals, as a papal bull.
Restoration: The act of restoring or bringing back to a former place, station, or condition; the fact of being restored; renewal; reëstablishment; as, the restoration of friendship between enemies; the restoration of peace after war.
Reverence: To regard or treat with reverence; to regard with respect and affection mingled with fear; to venerate.
Ruction: An uproar; a quarrel; a noisy outbreak.
recessional: a hymn or other piece of music sung or played while a church congregation is leaving a service, or a choir is returning to the cloak room; a recessional hymn.
Republican: One who favors or prefers a republican form of government.
&Verbar;Reticulum: The second stomach of ruminants, in which folds of the mucous membrane form hexagonal cells; -- also called the honeycomb stomach.
Regian: An upholder of kingly authority; a royalist.
Rictal: Of or pertaining to the rictus; as, rictal bristles.
Recognizance: An obligation of record entered into before some court of record or magistrate duly authorized, with condition to do some particular act, as to appear at the same or some other court, to keep the peace, or pay a debt. A recognizance differs from a bond, being witnessed by the record only, and not by the party's seal.
Reclinate: Reclined, as a leaf; bent downward, so that the point, as of a stem or leaf, is lower than the base.
Rosebud: The flower of a rose before it opens, or when but partially open.
Racy: Having a strong flavor indicating origin; of distinct characteristic taste; tasting of the soil; hence, fresh; rich.
Receivership: The state or office of a receiver.
Race: To cause to contend in a race; to drive at high speed; as, to race horses.
Ruminative: Inclined to, or engaged in, rumination or meditation.
&Verbar;Rytina: A genus of large edentulous sirenians, allied to the dugong and manatee, including but one species (Rytina Stelleri); -- called also Steller's sea cow, stellerine and steller.
Reconsider: To consider again; as, to reconsider a subject.
Rattinet: A woolen stuff thinner than ratteen.
Rach: A dog that pursued his prey by scent, as distinguished from the greyhound.
Remarque: A small design etched on the margin of a plate and supposed to be removed after the earliest proofs have been taken; also, any feature distinguishing a particular stage of the plate.
Rectify: To make or set right; to correct from a wrong, erroneous, or false state; to amend; as, to rectify errors, mistakes, or abuses; to rectify the will, the judgment, opinions; to rectify disorders.
Resorption: The act of resorbing; also, the act of absorbing again; reabsorption.
Requisition: To make a reqisition on or for; as, to requisition a district for forage; to requisition troops.
&Verbar;Ramayana: The more ancient of the two great epic poems in Sanskrit.  The hero and heroine are Rama and his wife Sita.
Randomize: to arrange or rearrange so that there is no predetermined order; to select by a random process; to assign (members of a group) into subgroups by a random process.
Regentship: The office of a regent; regency.
Recouch: To retire again to a couch; to lie down again.
Reviver: One who, or that which, revives.
Remontant: Rising again; -- applied to a class of roses which bloom more than once in a season; the hybrid perpetual roses, of which the Jacqueminot is a well-known example.
Rheic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid (commonly called chrysophanic acid) found in rhubarb (Rheum).
Reticule: A little bag, originally of network; a woman's workbag, or a little bag to be carried in the hand.
Remanence: The state of being remanent; continuance; permanence.
Relay: Relating to, or having the characteristics of, an auxiliary apparatus put into action by a feeble force but itself capable of exerting greater force, used to control a comparatively powerful machine or appliance.
Racer: One who, or that which, races, or contends in a race; esp., a race horse.
Reign: To possess or exercise sovereign power or authority; to exercise government, as a king or emperor;; to hold supreme power; to rule.
Roquelaure: A cloak reaching about to, or just below, the knees, worn in the 18th century.
Restorationism: The belief or doctrines of the Restorationists.
Renunciatory: Pertaining to renunciation; containing or declaring a renunciation; as, renunciatory vows.
Rose-red: Red as a rose; specifically (Zoöl.), of a pure purplish red color.
Raider: One who engages in a raid.
Revulsion: A strong pulling or drawing back; withdrawal.
Remissible: Capable of being remitted or forgiven.
Rotated: Turned round, as a wheel; also, wheel-shaped; rotate.
Ring-necked: Having a well defined ring of color around the neck.
Resin: Any one of a class of yellowish brown solid inflammable substances, of vegetable origin, which are nonconductors of electricity, have a vitreous fracture, and are soluble in ether, alcohol, and essential oils, but not in water; specif., pine resin (see Rosin).
Ratteen: A thick woolen stuff quilled or twilled.
Re\u00ebntering: The process of applying additional colors, by applications of printing blocks, to patterns already partly colored.
Resettle: To settle again, or a second time.
Rubescent: Growing or becoming red; tending to redness.
Rooted: Having taken root; firmly implanted; fixed in the heart.
Rebellious: Engaged in rebellion; disposed to rebel; of the nature of rebels or of rebellion; resisting government or lawful authority by force.
Retirade: A kind of retrenchment, as in the body of a bastion, which may be disputed inch by inch after the defenses are dismantled. It usually consists of two faces which make a reëntering angle.
Rusty: Covered or affected with rust; as, a rusty knife or sword; rusty wheat.
Rooter: One who, or that which, roots; one that tears up by the roots.
Right-about: A turning directly about by the right, so as to face in the opposite direction; also, the quarter directly opposite; as, to turn to the right-about.
Rat-tail: An excrescence growing from the pastern to the middle of the shank of a horse.
Rotative: turning, as a wheel; rotary; rotational.
Recourseful: Having recurring flow and ebb; moving alternately.
Rhizodont: A reptile whose teeth are rooted in sockets, as the crocodile.
Relapse: A sliding or falling back, especially into a former bad state, either of body or morals; backsliding; the state of having fallen back.
Resetter: One who resets, or sets again.
Romanic: Of or pertaining to Rome or its people.
Ruiner: One who, or that which, ruins.
Retrial: A secdond trial, experiment, or test; a second judicial trial, as of an accused person.
Roosa oil: The East Indian name for grass oil. See under Grass.
Redisseizin: A disseizin by one who once before was adjudged to have dassezed the same person of the same lands, etc.; also, a writ which lay in such a case.
Retaker: One who takes again what has been taken; a recaptor.
Rouncy: A common hackney horse; a nag.
Return: The act of returning (intransitive), or coming back to the same place or condition; as, the return of one long absent; the return of health; the return of the seasons, or of an anniversary.
&Verbar;Ricinus: A genus of plants of the Spurge family, containing but one species (Ricinus communis), the castor-oil plant.  The fruit is three-celled, and contains three large seeds from which castor oil is expressed. See Palma Christi.
Rabdomancy: Divination by means of rods or wands.
&Verbar;Raskolnik: The name applied by the Russian government to any subject of the Greek faith who dissents from the established church. The Raskolniki embrace many sects, whose common characteristic is a clinging to antique traditions, habits, and customs. The schism originated in 1667 in an ecclesiastical dispute as to the correctness of the translation of the religious books. The dissenters, who have been continually persecuted, are believed to number about 20,000,000, although the Holy Synod officially puts the number at about 2,000,000. They are officially divided into three groups according to the degree of their variance from orthodox beliefs and observances, as follows: I. “Most obnoxious.” the Judaizers; the Molokane, who refuse to recognize civil authority or to take oaths; the Dukhobortsy, or Dukhobors, who are communistic, marry without ceremony, and believe that Christ was human, but that his soul reappears at intervals in living men; the Khlysty, who countenance anthropolatory, are ascetics, practice continual self-flagellation, and reject marriage; the Skoptsy, who practice castration; and a section of the Bezpopovtsy, or priestless sect, which disbelieve in prayers for the Czar and in marriage. II. “Obnoxious:” the Bezpopovtsy, who pray for the Czar and recognize marriage. III. “Least obnoxious:” the Popovtsy, who dissent from the orthodox church in minor points only.
Renal calculus: an abnormal concretion formed in the excretory passages of the kidney, composed primarily of calcium oxalates and phosphates; -- also called kidney stone, nephrolith, and nephritic calculus (an obsolete term).
Ranunculus: A genus of herbs, mostly with yellow flowers, including crowfoot, buttercups, and the cultivated ranunculi (Ranunculus Asiaticus, Ranunculus aconitifolius, etc.) in which the flowers are double and of various colors.
Regular: A member of any religious order or community who has taken the vows of poverty, chastity, and obedience, and who has been solemnly recognized by the church.
Rotifer: One of the Rotifera. See Illust. in Appendix.
Rejuvenescent: Becoming, or causing to become, rejuvenated; rejuvenating.
Reputeless: Not having good repute; disreputable; disgraceful; inglorius.
Ratch: A ratchet wheel, or notched bar, with which a pawl or click works.
Recti-: A combining form signifying straight; as, rectilineal, having straight lines; rectinerved.
Refrigerate: To cause to become cool; to make or keep cold or cool.
Rehibitory: Of or relating to rehibition; as, a rehibitory action.
Resource: That to which one resorts orr on which one depends for supply or support; means of overcoming a difficulty; resort; expedient.
Renegade: One faithless to principle or party.
Reis: A common title in the East for a person in authority, especially the captain of a ship.
Requisitionist: One who makes or signs a requisition.
Re\u00ebxport: Any commodity reëxported; -- chiefly in the plural.
Ropery: A place where ropes are made.
Reim: A strip of oxhide, deprived of hair, and rendered pliable, -- used for twisting into ropes, etc.
Ricochet: To skip with a rebound or rebounds, as a flat stone on the surface of water, or a cannon ball on the ground. See Ricochet, n.
Riverhood: The quality or state of being a river.
Resident: One who resides or dwells in a place for some time.
Rose water: Water tinctured with roses by distillation.
Reasoning: The act or process of adducing a reason or reasons; manner of presenting one's reasons.
Rampancy: The quality or state of being rampant; excessive action or development; exuberance; extravagance.
Rurality: The quality or state of being rural.
Rinderpest: A highly contagious distemper or murrain, affecting neat cattle, and less commonly sheep and goats; -- called also cattle plague, Russian cattle plague, and steppe murrain.
Reshipment: The act of reshipping; also, that which is reshipped.
Retiring: Reserved; shy; not forward or obtrusive; as, retiring modesty; retiring manners.
Reach: The act of stretching or extending; extension; power of reaching or touching with the person, or a limb, or something held or thrown; as, the fruit is beyond my reach; to be within reach of cannon shot.
Right-handedness: The state or quality of being right-handed; hence, skill; dexterity.
Rheometric: Of or pertaining to a rheometer or rheometry.
Repristinate: To restore to an original state.
Recommission: To commission again; to give a new commission to.
Racemic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid found in many kinds of grapes. It is also obtained from tartaric acid, with which it is isomeric, and from sugar, gum, etc., by oxidation. It is a sour white crystalline substance, consisting of a combination of dextrorotatory and levorotatory tartaric acids.
&Verbar;Ribaudequin: An engine of war used in the Middle Ages, consisting of a protected elevated staging on wheels, and armed in front with pikes. It was (after the 14th century) furnished with small cannon.
Radicel: A small branch of a root; a rootlet.
Redfin: A small North American dace (Minnilus cornutus, or Notropis megalops). The male, in the breeding season, has bright red fins. Called also red dace, and shiner. Applied also to Notropis ardens, of the Mississippi valley.
Ration: To supply with rations, as a regiment.
Re\u00ebxaminable: Admitting of being reëxamined or reconsidered.
Reason: To arrange and present the reasons for or against; to examine or discuss by arguments; to debate or discuss; as, I reasoned the matter with my friend.
Regicidal: Pertaining to regicide, or to one committing it; having the nature of, or resembling, regicide.
Rhino-: A combining form from Greek &unr_;&unr_;, &unr_;&unr_;&unr_;, the nose, as in rhinolith, rhinology.
Rampant: Ramping; leaping; springing; rearing upon the hind legs; hence, raging; furious.
Regeneratory: Having power to renew; tending to reproduce; regenerating.
Recording: Keeping a record or a register; as, a recording secretary; -- applied to numerous instruments with an automatic appliance which makes a record of their action; as, a recording gauge or telegraph.
&Verbar;Respondentia: A loan upon goods laden on board a ship. It differs from bottomry, which is a loan on the ship itself.
Rearer: One who, or that which, rears.
Respersion: The act of sprinkling or scattering.
Reinvestment: The act of investing anew; a second or repeated investment.
&Verbar;Rhynchobdellea: A suborder of leeches including those that have a protractile proboscis, without jaws. Clepsine is the type.
Recriminatory: Having the quality of recrimination; retorting accusation; recriminating.
Rive: A place torn; a rent; a rift.
&Verbar;Rou\u00e9: One devoted to a life of sensual pleasure; a debauchee; a rake.
&Verbar;Rente: In France, interest payable by government on indebtedness; the bonds, shares, stocks, etc., which represent government indebtedness.
Rubicon: A small river which separated Italy from Cisalpine Gaul, the province alloted to Julius Cæsar.
Rheum: A serous or mucous discharge, especially one from the eves or nose.
Reservative: Tending to reserve or keep; keeping; reserving.
Ruminate: Having a hard albumen penetrated by irregular channels filled with softer matter, as the nutmeg and the seeds of the North American papaw.
Rectinerved: Having the veins or nerves straight; -- said of leaves.
&Verbar;Roturier: A person who is not of noble birth; specif., a freeman who during the prevalence of feudalism held allodial land.
Roumanian: An inhabitant of Roumania; also, the language of Roumania, one of the Romance or Romanic languages descended from Latin, but containing many words from other languages, as Slavic, Turkish, and Greek.
Revalescence: The act of growing well; the state of being revalescent.
Resty: Disposed to rest; indisposed toexercton; sluggish; also, restive.
Rebellion: The act of rebelling; open and avowed renunciation of the authority of the government to which one owes obedience, and resistance to its officers and laws, either by levying war, or by aiding others to do so; an organized uprising of subjects for the purpose of coercing or overthrowing their lawful ruler or government by force; revolt; insurrection.
Ringlestone: The ringed dotterel, or ring plover.
Raffia palm: A pinnate-leaved palm (Raphia ruffia) native of Madagascar, and of considerable economic importance on account of the strong fiber (raffia) obtained from its leafstalks.
Repossession: The act or the state of possessing again.
Reformatory: An institution for promoting the reformation of offenders.
Rough-grained: Having a rough grain or fiber; hence, figuratively, having coarse traits of character; not polished; brisque.
Refracting: Serving or tending to refract; as, a refracting medium.
Ricinelaidin: The glycerin salt of ricinelaidic acid, obtained as a white crystalline waxy substance by treating castor oil with nitrous acid.
Ruminantly: In a ruminant manner; by ruminating, or chewing the cud.
Richness: The quality or state of being rich (in any sense of the adjective).
Reverberant: Having the quality of reverberation; reverberating.
Ricinelaidic: Pertaining to, or designating, an isomeric modification of ricinoleic acid obtained as a white crystalline solid.
Raucous: Hoarse; harsh; rough; as, a raucous, thick tone.
Ramist: A follower of Pierre Ramé, better known as Ramus, a celebrated French scholar, who was professor of rhetoric and philosophy at Paris in the reign of Henry II., and opposed the Aristotelians.
Reformalize: To affect reformation; to pretend to correctness.
Retinite: An inflammable mineral resin, usually of a yellowish brown color, found in roundish masses, sometimes with coal.
&Verbar;Rasores: An order of birds; the Gallinæ.
Ruffianage: Ruffians, collectively; a body of ruffians.
Rose-pink: Having a pink color like that of the rose, or like the pigment called rose pink. See Rose pink, under Rose.
Respect: The act of noticing with attention; the giving particular consideration to; hence, care; caution.
Rangy: Inclined or able to range, or rove about, for considerable distances; apt or suited for much roving, -- chiefly used of cattle.
&Verbar;R\u00e9duit: A central or retired work within any other work.
Racking: Spun yarn used in racking ropes.
Range: A series of things in a line; a row; a rank; as, a range of buildings; a range of mountains.
Ruperts drop: A kind of glass drop with a long tail, made by dropping melted glass into water. It is remarkable for bursting into fragments when the surface is scratched or the tail broken; -- so called from Prince Rupert, nephew of Charles I., by whom they were first brought to England. Called also Rupert's ball, and glass tear.
Redraw: To draw a new bill of exchange, as the holder of a protested bill, on the drawer or indorsers.
Rudderhole: The hole in the deck through which the rudderpost passes.
Retractation: The act of retracting what has been said; recantation.
Ruthenium: A rare element of the light platinum group, found associated with platinum ores, and isolated as a hard, brittle steel-gray metal which is very infusible.  Symbol Ru.  Atomic weight 103.5. Specific gravity 12.26. See Platinum metals, under Platinum.
Ruination: The act of ruining, or the state of being ruined.
Red dog: The lowest grade of flour in milling. It is dark and of little expansive power, is secured largely from the germ or embryo and adjacent parts, and contains a relatively high percentage of protein. It is chiefly useful as feed for farm animals.
Raging: a. & n. from Rage, v. i.
Recuperate: To recover; to regain; as, to recuperate the health or strength.
Revince: To overcome; to refute, as error.
Refind: To find again; to get or experience again.
Refine: To become pure; to be cleared of feculent matter.
Rockered: Shaped like a rocker; curved; as, a rockered keel.
&Verbar;Replum: The framework of some pods, as the cress, which remains after the valves drop off.
Retting: The act or process of preparing flax for use by soaking, maceration, and kindred processes; -- also called rotting. See Ret.
Riflebird: Any one of several species of beautiful birds of Australia and New Guinea, of the genera Ptiloris and Craspidophora, allied to the paradise birds.
Rape: A name given to a variety or to varieties of a plant of the turnip kind, grown for seeds and herbage. The seeds are used for the production of rape oil, and to a limited extent for the food of cage birds.
Really: In a real manner; with or in reality; actually; in truth.
Repressive: Having power, or tending, to repress; as, repressive acts or measures.
Roselle: a malvaceous plant (Hibiscus Sabdariffa) cultivated in the east and West Indies for its fleshy calyxes, which are used for making tarts and jelly and an acid drink.
Rubescence: The quality or state of being rubescent; a reddening; a flush.
Remissly: In a remiss or negligent manner; carelessly.
Resolutioner: One who makes a resolution; one who joins with others in a declaration or resolution; specifically, one of a party in the Scottish Church in the 17th century.
Radiciform: Having the nature or appearance of a radix or root.
Rehibition: The returning of a thing purchased to the seller, on the ground of defect or frand.
Regreet: A return or exchange of salutation.
Reckon: To make an enumeration or computation; to engage in numbering or computing.
Remunerate: To pay an equivalent to for any service, loss, expense, or other sacrifice; to recompense; to requite; as, to remunerate men for labor.
Rabidness: The quality or state of being rabid.
Retrenchment: The act or process of retrenching; as, the retrenchment of words in a writing.
Re-presentation: The act of re-presenting, or the state of being presented again; a new presentation; as, re-presentation of facts previously stated.
Rule: To have power or command; to exercise supreme authority; -- often followed by over.
Remindful: Tending or adapted to remind; careful to remind.
Ribibe: A sort of stringed instrument; a rebec.
Remitment: The act of remitting, or the state of being remitted; remission.
Rivalry: The act of rivaling, or the state of being a rival; a competition.
Recontinuance: The act or state of recontinuing.
Repaint: To paint anew or again; as, to repaint a house; to repaint the ground of a picture.
Ratter: One who, or that which, rats, as one who deserts his party.
Rheochord: A metallic wire used for regulating the resistance of a circuit, or varying the strength of an electric current, by inserting a greater or less length of it in the circuit.
Ragnarok: The so-called “Twilight of the Gods” (called in German Götterdämmerung), the final destruction of the world in the great conflict between the Æsir (gods) on the one hand, and on the other, the giants and the powers of Hel under the leadership of Loki (who is escaped from bondage).
Recurviroster: A bird whose beak bends upward, as the avocet.
Roman calendar: The calendar of the ancient Romans, from which our modern calendars are derived. It is said to have consisted originally of ten months, Martius, Aprilis, Maius, Junius, Quintilis, Sextilis, September, October, November, and December, having a total of 304 days. Numa added two months, Januarius at the beginning of the year, and Februarius at the end, making in all 355 days. He also ordered an intercalary month, Mercedinus, to be inserted every second year. Later the order of the months was changed so that January should come before February. Through abuse of power by the pontiffs to whose care it was committed, this calendar fell into confusion. It was replaced by the Julian calendar. In designating the days of the month, the Romans reckoned backward from three fixed points, the calends, the nones, and the ides. The calends were always the first day of the month. The ides fell on the 15th in March, May, July (Quintilis), and October, and on the 13th in other months. The nones came on the eighth day (the ninth, counting the ides) before the ides. Thus, Jan. 13 was called the ides of January, Jan. 12, the day before the ides, and Jan. 11, the third day before the ides (since the ides count as one), while Jan. 14 was the 19th day before the calends of February.
Remittee: One to whom a remittance is sent.
Rhodic: Of or pertaining to rhodium; containing rhodium.
Ratten: To deprive feloniously of the tools used in one's employment (as by breaking or stealing them), for the purpose of annoying; as, to ratten a mechanic who works during a strike.
Rehear: To hear again; to try a second time; as, to rehear a cause in Chancery.
Refracture: To break again, as a bone.
Redtop: A kind of grass (Agrostis vulgaris) highly valued in the United States for pasturage and hay for cattle; -- called also English grass, and in some localities herd's grass. See Illustration in Appendix. The tall redtop is Triodia seslerioides.
Relate: To stand in some relation; to have bearing or concern; to pertain; to refer; -- with to.
&Verbar;Reichsstand: A free city of the former German empire.
Redness: The quality or state of being red; red color.
Regulize: To reduce to regulus; to separate, as a metal from extraneous matter; as, to regulize antimony.
Realm: A royal jurisdiction or domain; a region which is under the dominion of a king; a kingdom.
Retarder: One who, or that which, retards.
Recipience: The quality or state of being recipient; a receiving; reception; receptiveness.
Rye: A grain yielded by a hardy cereal grass (Secale cereale), closely allied to wheat; also, the plant itself.  Rye constitutes a large portion of the breadstuff used by man.
Rotular: Of or pertaining to the rotula, or kneepan.
Reft: A chink; a rift. See Rift.
Rustic: An inhabitant of the country, especially one who is rude, coarse, or dull; a clown.
Reforestation: replanting with trees; reconversion into a forest; the act of reforesting.
Recumbence: The act of leaning, resting, or reclining; the state of being recumbent.
Rescribe: To write back; to write in reply.
Reef-band: A piece of canvas sewed across a sail to strengthen it in the part where the eyelet holes for reefing are made.
Ruralism: The quality or state of being rural; ruralness.
Respectless: Having no respect; without regard; regardless.
Ruly: Orderly; easily restrained; -- opposed to unruly.
Regretful: Full of regret; indulging in regrets; repining.
Reconvention: A cross demand; an action brought by the defendant against the plaintiff before the same judge.
Ruralist: One who leads a rural life.
Remedy: To apply a remedy to; to relieve; to cure; to heal; to repair; to redress; to correct; to counteract.
Relucent: Reflecting light; shining; glittering; glistening; bright; luminous; splendid.
Rationale: An explanation or exposition of the principles of some opinion, action, hypothesis, phenomenon, or the like; also, the principles themselves.
Rotate: To cause to turn round or revolve, as a wheel around an axle.
Rhabdite: A minute smooth rodlike or fusiform structure found in the tissues of many Turbellaria.
Route: The course or way which is traveled or passed, or is to be passed; a passing; a course; a road or path; a march.
Resistibility: The quality of being resistible; resistibleness.
Remove: The act of removing; a removal.
Rescriptive: Pertaining to, or answering the purpose of, a rescript; hence, deciding; settling; determining.
&Verbar;Rhizophaga: A division of marsupials. The wombat is the type.
Relievement: The act of relieving, or the state of being relieved; relief; release.
Regress: To go back; to return to a former place or state.
Rootery: A pile of roots, set with plants, mosses, etc., and used as an ornamental object in gardening.
Rest-harrow: A European leguminous plant (Ononis arvensis) with long, tough roots.
Rebiting: The act or process of deepening worn lines in an etched plate by submitting it again to the action of acid.
Radicalism: The quality or state of being radical; specifically, the doctrines or principles of radicals in politics or social reform.
Rubiretin: One of the red dye products extracted from madder root, and probably identical with ruberythrinic acid.
Refiner: One who, or that which, refines.
Reflected: Thrown back after striking a surface; as, reflected light, heat, sound, etc.
Risibility: The quality of being risible; as, risibility is peculiar to the human species.
Ryot: A peasant or cultivator of the soil.
Ro-setta stone: A stone found at Rosetta, in Egypt, bearing a trilingual inscription, by aid of which, with other inscriptions, a key was obtained to the hieroglyphics of ancient Egypt.
Refined: Freed from impurities or alloy; purifed; polished; cultured; delicate; as; refined gold; refined language; refined sentiments.
Roussette: A fruit bat, especially the large species (Pieropus vulgaris) inhabiting the islands of the Indian ocean.  It measures about a yard across the expanded wings.
Recuperative: Of or pertaining to recuperation; tending to recovery.
